results.description:
Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us again THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join me for a beginner west coast swing class from 8:30-9:15pm (Experienced with WCS? Join Marcus Schwarz for the Intermediate class at 8:30!). If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-11pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Beginner & Intermediate West Coast Swing Class & Social Dance!

group.name: Learn how to social dance in Burlington Mass!

results.description:
Let's dance salsa!

Friday Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party on Friday featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away!

9:00-10:00pm:  Beginner & Intermediate. Salsa Lessons
10:00-2am: Dance Party * No Partner Required

Lets meet at 9 pm (facing the stage) at the right side of the stage.

There are some tables alongside the wall. These tables are typically first come, first serve, so if we all arrive at the same time and early, we can occupy these tables.

I will make some Meetup signs and try to post them at these tables.  These tables can serve as our meeting point through out the night.  Last time I asked for permission and  management informed me that posting signs was not allowed.  I may not ask for permission this time and discretely post a night flat on the table.  

I also have some neon/glow-in-the-dark bracelets and necklaces that I plan to wear and pass out to members of the group so we can recognize each other more easily.

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  This is an actual event, not an advertisement. 

Please be on time! If you arrive late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to recognize members of the group from the crowds.

This should be a super fun event and a super friendly event for salsa beginners and the advanced dancers.


I am really looking forward to enjoying this event as part of the group.

Wear comfortable shoes!

Joana

******************************************************************************************************************************

Event Details

Beginners Very Welcome

No partner required

$12 - Admission includes lesson and party

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant (No ball caps, no work boots, etc.)

Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar

Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata, 10% merengue/cha cha

***********************************
Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St.

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr)parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk.

Please note that the Night Salsa parties are 21+.

* Don't forget your ID!

http://www.havanaclubsalsa.com/salsa_fridays.shtml

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.

results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

results.description:
The Jaycee walking club!
I am extending you this invite to get you moving!
We meet Saturday mornings, 7:45 am, Fruit Street Mansfield, WW II Veterans Memorial Trail (Bike Path). Just past the airport. We go for just about a 4 mile walk, takes a little over an hour, and we have lots of fun. If you can’t do the 4 miles come and do what you can and work your way up. We usually have enough people to split up into sub-groups of leisure walkers and speedsters.

I use Map My Walk to keep track of our time and distance. This is a free app that you can download to your smartphone, should you want to start keeping track of your exercise, minutes and calories burned. It has a lot of features that I am sure you would have fun with.

If you can, let me know if you will be walking with us, so we don’t start without you. If we are all gathered before 8 we tend to just get going at that point.

If you are interested in joining our walking club, either this time or sometime in the future, please let me know and I will include you on that email list.
Laureen House [masked]
results.name: Foxboro Jaycees Walking Club

results.description:
Hi Ladies:

Meghan at Foster Fitness is offering a free trial class Saturday at 8 a.m. at her studio in Wakefield MA  (411 Lowell St.)

I joined Meghan about a month ago and love it (Thank you Julia Rodrigues:)

If you are looking to start an exercise program, make changes to your current program, join me at this free class.  

Foster Fitness offers small group size workouts of all ages and fitness levels.

About the class:  This one is my favorite it is called 50/50   This class will give you a little taste of both the lift and sweat and also won't be overwhelming for  anyone who has not worked out in a while.

More from Megan:

My name is Meghan McClorey and I am the owner/trainer at Foster Fitness. I want to help you live the best life possible. I plan on doing this by educating you on simple changes you can make to create a healthier lifestyle, motivating you when times get rough, and demonstrating to you that your body is capable of so much more than you believe.Why Foster Fitness?  At foster fitness we want to help you reach your goals and live the life you imagine.
E.A.R.N. results.
Foster Fitness is here to help YOU achieve YOUR goals. 
We Do This Through Our E.A.R.N. Principle
Empower 
 YOU CAN DO IT. With encouragement, people in your corner, and the strength of your own will you will achieve any goal you set for yourself.
Accomplishment
By pushing you just out of your comfort zone. By doing something you have never experienced. You will own your workouts. Your confidence will skyrocket. You will want more.
Results 
 Will be seen. You will sweat. You will burn. You will feel the results 
Nutrition
The hidden key to unlocking the body you want to look back at you in the mirror and having more energy than ever before.

Why me? I have a BS in sports medicine as I was originally thinking physical therapy was my dream career. Shortly after starting college, I began a formal strength and conditioning regimen with my soccer team. I have always played sports and have always worked out but this was the first time that I knew I belonged in the fitness world. I saw improvements in my performance on and off the field. I gained confidence in my ability to go up against players much bigger than me (I am only 5’2”!). Most importantly, I stayed in the game by staying injury free. 
After college, I took up running and triathlons. I am now competitive in local sprint triathlons and have completed 9 marathons and 3 IRONMANS. I have seen how much better I perform when I am consistent with my strength and conditioning program. It improves my endurance as well as mental toughness. It also makes me appreciate and love my body (and not for nothing, it makes wearing a bikini at the beach fun!). I started 1 on 1 personal training in college after receiving my certification through ACSM. Since then I have worked in many atmospheres including a big gym, private studio, sports performance center, outdoor boot camps, and now for myself. I have helped clients lose weight, build muscle, lower their BP and cholesterol, stabilize their blood sugar, complete races, and prepare and exceed in their upcoming seasons/races. 
I am a nerd at heart and love reading anything regarding the current trends and studies in health and fitness. I also love to try new things: workout trends, gear, and food/supplements.  I am constantly learning to bring the best to my clients and to keep them, as well as myself, on their toes. 


<a href="https://us-mg5.mail.yahoo.com/neo/launch?.rand=c5275u8lfdhn4#"></a>
results.name: FREE TRIAL CLASS FOSTER FITNESS - WAKEFIELD MA

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!

results.description:
We will visit the caves where Sarah Clayes and others escaped prosecution as Salem witches.


This 1.5 mile walk is on what was the plantation of former governor Thomas Danforth. Sarah Clayes was one of the five women who lived in one of these caves for the winter of 1692, until the hysteria over witches passed. The accused and their families were a significant portion of the initial population of Framingham.


This will be a short, relatively gentle walk of about 1.5 miles. Bring your witches broom. Please wear sturdy shoes and bring sun screen. The walk will cancel for rain.

AMC leader Chris Stix will lead.  To contact, click here.

results.name: Hike to see the "witches" caves in Ashland

results.description:
This is  ultra HUGE !!  At the Reggie Lewis Center...

Saturday & Sunday, October 24 & 25 -
20th Anniversary Boston Veg Food Fest!
FREE Admission!

20th Annual Boston Veg Food Fest! 


http://bostonveg.org/foodfest/ 
FREE Admission! (after 11 am on Saturday)

The Boston Vegetarian Society proudly presents 
The 20th Anniversary Boston Veg Food Fest

Saturday, October 24, 2015, 11AM* - 6PM 
and 
Sunday, October 25, 2015, 10AM - 4PM

*Saturday 10 - 11 AM preview hour. A limited number of tickets ($5) will be available online in September to visit the Exhibitor Room before the doors open at 11 AM for Free Admission to all.

Reggie Lewis Athletic Center 
1350 Tremont Street, Boston, Massachusetts 
Orange Line Subway stop (Roxbury Crossing) across the street

This Festival brings together an amazing array of vegetarian natural food providers, top national speakers and chefs, and educational exhibitors in a fun and welcoming environment. It is a chance to talk directly to food producers, learn the newest items in the marketplace, taste free food samples, shop at show special discounts, or simply learn what vegetarian foods are available and where you can find them!

See the BVFF 2014 subway ads on the BVFF site

Ad 1: Click to enlarge 

Ad 2: Click to enlarge 

Whether you are a longtime vegetarian or vegan, or someone simply wanting to add more delicious plant-based foods to your meal repertoire, or if you are just curious what it's all about, you are welcome here! We offer you free admission, free food sampling, free speaker presentations, free parking and a T stop across the street. 

You also can learn of ways to help animals and protect the environment, and enhance your health and well being. There are activities for kids, too!

Saturday & Sunday, October 24 & 25 - 
20th Anniversary Boston Veg Food Fest! 
FREE Admission!

• We hope you are getting ready to attend the Festival today and tomorrow! 

Come and be greeted by Ms. Cow, who wears a banner reading,
Don't Have a Cow
Go Veggie!
Kindness is Delicious

Don't Have a Cow
Go Veggie!
Kindness is Delicious 

Here is our Directions page. 

The best way to reach the Boston Veg Food Fest at the Reggie Lewis Athletic Center, 1350 Tremont Street in Boston, is to take the T. 

Take the Orange Line to Roxbury Crossing station, and we are diagonally across the street from the T station! 

Parking: 

There is some free street parking in the area -- watch the signs. 

There are two free parking lots just beyond the block of academic buildings at Roxbury Community College, marked as Lot 1 and Lot 2 on this parking map -- note that Lot 3 is no longer available. 

Here is a tip about parking to share with our list: 

In addition to Lots 1 and 2  noted on the parking map, there are parking spaces behind Madison Park School, which is next to the Reggie Lewis Center. You reach this from a driveway on Tremont St. 

There isn't an address for the parking lot to give for GPS, so here goes: 

Driving on Tremont Street, pass Reggie Lewis on your right, then Whittier Street Health Center. Immediately turn right into a driveway and drive down a very small hill to a red STOP sign. Go straight through the  stop sign to the parking behind the school. The signs about needing a Madison Park School permit apply only to week days, and the school said that parking there on the weekend is fine. There are 50-75 spaces, they estimated. 

At the STOP sign noted above, do NOT turn left into the larger parking area, as that is permit only and they do tow from that lot. 

It should be a great weekend!

Boston Veg Food Fest Organizing Committee 

Kellian Adams, Robin Adams, Charles Bosse, Erica Farrell, Melissa Gannon, Stephanie Golas, David Havelick, Evelyn Kimber, Beverly Rich, Dan Stackhouse, Venkat Vedam

20th Anniversary Boston Veg Food Fest!
FREE Admission!

20th Annual Boston Veg Food Fest! 


http://bostonveg.org/foodfest/ 
FREE Admission! (after 11 am on Saturday)

The Boston Vegetarian Society proudly presents 
The 20th Anniversary Boston Veg Food Fest

Saturday, October 24, 2015, 11AM* - 6PM 
and 
Sunday, October 25, 2015, 10AM - 4PM

*Saturday 10 - 11 AM preview hour. A limited number of tickets ($5) will be available online in September to visit the Exhibitor Room before the doors open at 11 AM for Free Admission to all.

Reggie Lewis Athletic Center 
1350 Tremont Street, Boston, Massachusetts 
Subway stop across the street

This Festival brings together an amazing array of vegetarian natural food providers, top national speakers and chefs, and educational exhibitors in a fun and welcoming environment. It is a chance to talk directly to food producers, learn the newest items in the marketplace, taste free food samples, shop at show special discounts, or simply learn what vegetarian foods are available and where you can find them!

See the BVFF 2014 subway ads on the BVFF site

Ad 1: Click to enlarge 

Ad 2: Click to enlarge


Whether you are a longtime vegetarian or vegan, or someone simply wanting to add more delicious plant-based foods to your meal repertoire, or if you are just curious what it's all about, you are welcome here! We offer you free admission, free food sampling, free speaker presentations, free parking and a T stop across the street. 

You also can learn of ways to help animals and protect the environment, and enhance your health and well being. There are activities for kids, too!

We hope you are getting ready to attend the Festival today and tomorrow! Come and be greeted by Ms. Cow, who wears a banner reading,
Don't Have a Cow
Go Veggie!
Kindness is Delicious 

Here is our Directions page. 

The best way to reach the Boston Veg Food Fest at the Reggie Lewis Athletic Center, 1350 Tremont Street in Boston, is to take the T. 

Take the Orange Line to Roxbury Crossing station, and we are diagonally across the street from the T station! 

Parking: 

There is some free street parking in the area -- watch the signs. 

There are two free parking lots just beyond the block of academic buildings at Roxbury Community College, marked as Lot 1 and Lot 2 on this parking map -- note that Lot 3 is no longer available. 

Here is a tip about parking to share with our list: 

In addition to Lots 1 and 2  noted on the parking map, there are parking spaces behind Madison Park School, which is next to the Reggie Lewis Center. You reach this from a driveway on Tremont St. 

There isn't an address for the parking lot to give for GPS, so here goes: 

Driving on Tremont Street, pass Reggie Lewis on your right, then Whittier Street Health Center. Immediately turn right into a driveway and drive down a very small hill to a red STOP sign. Go straight through the  stop sign to the parking behind the school. The signs about needing a Madison Park School permit apply only to week days, and the school said that parking there on the weekend is fine. There are 50-75 spaces, they estimated. 

At the STOP sign noted above, do NOT turn left into the larger parking area, as that is permit only and they do tow from that lot. 

It should be a great weekend!

Boston Veg Food Fest Organizing Committee 

Kellian Adams, Robin Adams, Charles Bosse, Erica Farrell, Melissa Gannon, Stephanie Golas, David Havelick, Evelyn Kimber, Beverly Rich, Dan Stackhouse, Venkat Vedam

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the school (left side of the church), enter under the green awning, then up two flights to the gym!
results.name: (Cambridge) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling

group.name: Boston Armizare -- Historical Swordplay and More!

results.description:
Run Details: Meet up with The Most Informal Running Club Ever at 10:00am for the weekly Saturday Fun Run. We'll split up into groups depending on the turnout for distance and time goals for 4, 6 or 7 mile loops. It's your choice!

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It's that easy.

Breakfast Details : Between 11:15 and 11:30 (depending on how long we run) we will meet back at City Sports on Comm Ave. near Packards Corner for Pot Luck style brunch.

Contribute to a great breakfast with an item to share with the group (eggs, bagels, fruits, muffins, juice, bacon, potatoes, etc.) You're not obligated to bring anything, though, so please join us for breakfast after the run anyway.

ALL ABILITY LEVELS WELCOME!!!

Secret parking is accessible in the Star Market parking lot (just make sure you walk through Star Market. No one has ever been towed.)

Bring a friend, see you out there.


informalrunning.com


Read the BLOG

results.description:
This event pertains to the general beekeeping community, and is not an official BABA event.

This workshop begins with a lecture and discussion about the hive through winter, and then ends with an optional construction clinic where participants can assemble their own winterization system. 


The lecture will be led by Kristin McDonnell, a Boston beekeeper for over eight years with a strong track record keeping colonies alive through winter. She now has 20 colonies ranging from an observation hive to nucs to many full-sized Langstroths. Kristin emphasizes that “successful overwintering is THE key to good beekeeping.”


Kristin will cover the colony’s winter physiology (the clusters' location, population, metabolism,...), as well as various theories about insulation/winterization (to wrap or not to wrap, ventilation, snow cover, overwintering indoors,...).


During part two you will have the opportunity to assemble a "quilt box" and/or a homasote-based moisture control system which you can place right onto your hives. All necessary tools will be on hand, and materials will be available to purchase. Attend the workshop and go home ready to tuck your bees in snug and cozy for winter!

To register and pay, go to Brown Paper Tickets at http://bpt.me/2412173 . For questions, please call[masked]-7378.
results.name: Winterize Your Beehive

results.description:
I am a member of the Boston Harbor Sailing Club and will be taking out a 31 ft. Pearson for a day sail. After sailing, those interested can stay for dinner/drinks at a local watering hole.

Please have at least some sailing experience and be able to raise sails, help with anchoring, mooring, and sail trim.

You should plan on bringing your lunch and one snack to share. Also be sure to bring water to drink (one liter is about right), hat, sunscreen, and boat-friendly shoes. It gets breezy this time of year, so bring warm layers.

We will meet under the arch at Rowes Wharf. It's a short walk from the Aquarium T stop on the Blue Line or you can park for only $7 at the International Place garage if you print out their coupon ($10 without the coupon).

http://bostonparking.spplus.com/Boston-1-International-Place-Parking.html

I will select crew based on sailing experience. Please RSVP for the wait list and provide your cell phone number and a brief summary of your sailing experience when you RSVP. You don't need to be an "expert", but should have at least some experience.  I will select crew at around noon Friday Oct. 23.

Should be a great day for a sail!
results.how_to_find_us: Under the archway at Rowes Wharf
results.name: Last Sail of the Summer!

results.description:
A quality, nourishing soup can meet all of your needs: fill a belly, cure a cold, or serve as a party entree, afternoon snack, or warm hiking companion. All good soups start with one basic ingredient: a high quality broth. The better your broth, the better your soup. Learn to make rich, nourishing soups with nutritional consultant Gena Mavuli. During the workshop, she will demo one homemade broth and two soups, and we’ll do plenty of tasting. Get ready to get your hands dirty as you help cut, chop, and simmer.

Tuition is $20 per person. Workshop is hosted by Wright-Locke Farm. Registration via wlfarm.org is REQUIRED (option to pay the day of the event is available).

CLICK HERE TO REGISTER: https://www.wlfarm.org/get-involved?page=CiviCRM&q=civicrm/event/register&reset=1&id=198
results.name: Healthy Soup Making Workshop

results.description:
Are you overly sensitive to sight, sound, smell, touch and feelings? Do you absorb everyone’s problems like they are your own?Do you have problems with processing these emotions?


Everyone is an empath to some degree. Some people know how to process overwhelming emotions and set boundaries but many don’t know how. If you are an empath who is overwhelmed by your emotions and want to learn how to release this energy, then this workshop is for you.


Living in an emotional realm can be frustrating and confusing when you don’t understand your processing system. You start to feel unbalanced. The key is to understand how to develop skills to protect you from chaotic energy.


In this workshop, Sue will create a sacred space and teach you how to ground and aligned your self with your own rhythm and energy system. Skills on releasing and processing the chaotic energy will be taught. When you are clear on what emotions are yours then you are able to clearly align with your life purpose.


Come join Sue Angelo as she shares her wisdom, experience, and deep love for Shamanic practice in this weekend workshop! Come prepared to drum, meditate, and journey outside on the land. (weather permitting) Sue will conduct the workshop outside as much as possible so please come prepared with appropriate clothing, blankets, etc. You may bring a brown bag lunch (include ice pack) or visit one of the many sandwich shops located within walking distance in Topsfield Village. Lots of water, a pen and journal are necessary tools for the day!


Pre-registration is required as space is limited.

http://blossomhealings.com/event/shamanic-practice-series-2-4/?instance_id=50532


Weather permitting, a majority of this workshop will take place outdoors. Please dress accordingly.


Part 1 & 2 – October 24 from 10am-4pm


What is Shamanism ? - The discussion will begin with definitions about Shamanism and the different practices. The tools and methods of Shamanism will be explored. The beliefs are that the connection to the energies of Mother Earth and the connection to the energies of Spirit help you grow and learn, ultimately expanding your horizons.These beliefs are used in healings to clear trauma and discover your personal power. Shamanic Journeying will be introduced in this session.


Grounding and Spiritual Hygiene - Working in the “Non -Ordinary Realm” and what does that look like? Connecting to the rhythms and forces of nature though rituals and sacred ceremony . Learning that healing can occur through ritual and ceremonies and how to create the sacred space and protection to prepare for your own ritual.Grounding yourself so that you are aligned with the rhythm of your life purpose and connection with spirit.

Part 3 & 4 – October 25 from 10am-4pm

Animal Totems - Working to reconnect conscious humans with Nature and Spirit through your Animal Totems.Holding reverence for Nature around us and working with our Animal Totems. Aligning with our Animal Totems will help us to understand the archetype energy and our own powers. Sacred Space will be set and you will journey to the lower world to meet your Animal Totem. There will be time to discuss the meanings of your animal totem and your journey.Soul RetrievalsIn shamanism it is believed that a part of a human soul is free to leave the physical body when it feels emotional or physically challenged. 

Soul retrieval-Where does the soul go? The soul will astral travel outside of the body going through time and space to find answers, wisdom and lost power. Once answers are found, the soul returns but sometimes the soul doesn’t return or gets lost? A Soul Retrieval is needed.One of a Shamanic Practitioner’s healing tools is the ability to retrieve souls and bring it back to its owner. If you feel lost, emotionally and physically drained, or something is missing this is the right workshop for you.For this journey Sue will create a sacred, loving and safe space for a soul retrieval ceremony. Sue will call upon our spirit guides, ancestors for help and use a drum to journey to find our souls, retrieve and return them. After the ceremony participants will feel complete, lighter and balanced.Reasons of why portions of the souls leaved the body will be discussed. A discussion will occur to determine which portion of your soul wants to be retrieved during the journey. Sacred space will be set and a Shamanic journey will be used for the Soul Retrieval. The participate must be open to receiving this portion so the healing can begin. There will be time to share your experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Will be held at private residence in Topsfield, Ma.
results.name: Shamanic Weekend Workshop/Topsfield

results.description:
The North River is primarily salt water tidal river, fed by several freshwater sources. It is a state-designated Wildlife Sanctuary.
We will meet at the Marshfield Canoe Launch, which coincidentally is located on the Norwell side of the River on Bridge Street. A GPS address of 41 Bridge St
Norwell, MA 02061 should get you close. You will see a parking area with a boat ramp off to the side of the bridge.
We will launch approximately 1 hour after ocean high tide. The current will be heading gently inward, so we will follow it (away from the Union Street Bridge and the ocean). About an hour upstream is Couch Beach, which is a nice stopping point. We will break here for a rest and snack. By this time the tide will have gently switched directions and we will return to the launch site. This is a trip for all levels of experience. The tidal current is minimal. Total trip distance is about 7 miles.
"Water is the driving force of all nature."...Leonardo Da Vinci
results.name: Explore the North River and view Near Peak Foliage

results.description:
Let's meet for a Saturday Morning Multi-Group SINGLES Walk in the Park @ Pond Meadow Park!  This is one of our favorite walking locations.  We will be meeting on the Braintree side of PMP by the flagpole in front of the Ranger Station. 

Let’s enjoy the fall foliage as we get to know singles from the 4 meetup groups listed below.  All single members of the groups listed below are invited to join us.  The Singles category for our purpose is anyone who is not married, engaged, or in a committed long-term relationship.  Basically, you're not otherwise attached and may or may not be dating.  No pressure here, just a chance to bond and get to know other singles in our meetup groups. 

[Please Note: There are only two entrances to PMP - in Braintree and Weymouth.  There is only one place to meet on the path and that's where the Braintree and Weymouth paths converge.  If we walk against the flow of traffic and you will be more than 10 minutes late you could potentially meet us at the merge as we will wait 5-10 minutes for late (Yes RSVP) arrivals, and within 5-10 minutes of our departure we will pass the convergence of the paths.  However, if we walk the right away we won't pass that point until almost 1/2 hour into our walk.]

The loop is 1.6 miles, with the walk to and from the parking lot it is 1.9 miles.  It takes about 35-40 minutes to walk the loop.  If we walk the loop twice it's a total of 3.5 miles and takes between 1 hr and 1 hr and 15 minutes, depending on pace.  If we walk to the street of the Weymouth entrance it adds .4 miles and takes about 5-10 minutes.

This is a multi-group event as listed below.  Please do not double or triple RSVP.  It may co$t ya.

Social Fun: www.meetup.com/socialfun

South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club: www.meetup.com/socialnetwork-1414

South of Boston, Norwood Singles Social Events/Dating Meetup: http://www.meetup.com/Norwood-Singles-Social-Events-and-Dating-Meetup/

Christian Dating/Social Events, Norwood, South of Boston: http://www.meetup.com/Christian-Dating-Social-Events-Norwood-South-of-Boston/

We are asking each group to have a co-host to help with attendance (for your particular group), and with keeping everyone involved in the walk.  Groups without a co-host will be limited to 6 participants, including the Host.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Saturday Morning Singles Social Walk!

Saturday, October 24th @ 10:45am

Pond Meadow Park

470 Liberty Street, Braintree

Sorry, no phone #.

Meeting Location: Please meet by the flagpole in front of the Ranger Station.

Event Host/(s)/Organizer(s): Angela & Liam / Laura is Co-Host for SOBNSSEDM and CDSENSOB, however, if another member of either of those groups wants to co-host please let one or both of us know as we will be happy to have you join us.  Cindy W is Co-Host for SF.  Liam is Co-Host for SSHBSC.


Min/Max: We are requesting at least 10 Yes RSVPs among all groups (excluding the Host) at least one week prior to the event.  Each group will start with a max of 6 which will be increased to 10 once we have an Event Co-Host in place and a WaitList.  The maximum total for this event is 40 people between all groups and I will adjust the max in each group accordingly 4-5 days prior to the event.  

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 8pm on Friday, October 23rd.  Any changes to your RSVP after this time or anyone who is a Yes RSVP at this time but does not attend the event may be considered a No-Show.  RSVPs will close approximately 2 hours prior to the event @ 8:30am which means no new RSVPs (or RSVP changes) will be allowed after this time.

Fee: Fee: Since this is an event for multiple meetup groups and they all have different policies for fees and such, there will be no fees for today's event.  However, if you belong to a group that does have fees or voluntary donations I will gladly accept it and pass it along.


Inclement Weather: Heavy rains will cancel.  We will walk if it is overcast or there is a slight drizzle.  Please plan to bring a lightweight jacket with a hood just in case.  (We will do my best to notify everyone if this event is cancelled by 9am on the day of the walk.)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions: Best directions should be taken from mapquest.com or maps.google.com. Located on Liberty Street, 500 feet from the intersection of Liberty and Middle Street near the Route 3 overpass directly across from Zana Park Drive.

Please note there is a rotary now instead of a regular intersection just before PMP.

From Route 3: Take Exit 17/Union St., Braintree.  Exit on the side of the (Sunoco) Gas Station and Police Station.  Follow Union Street to the first set of lights.  Take a Right at the lights onto Middle Street.  Follow about 1 mile to a Rotary.  Go 3/4 of the way around the Rotary and exit onto Liberty Street.  (This used to be a regular intersection where you took a left.)  PMP is 500 feet up on the Right.

Parking: There are 4 lots on the Braintree side.  The first lot is outside the gate right off Liberty Street.  The second lot is just after the flagpole around the corner (where there are a couple of spots before you turn).  The last two lots are at the bottom of the hill inside the 2nd gate after you pass by the flagpole.  The first of these two lots is a grassy area on the right at the bottom of the hill just before a set of yellow gates.  The 2nd of these two lots is just past the set of yellow gates on your left and is paved.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Note: All of my events are child-free and pet-free for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted.  Thank you for being respectful of this request.

results.name: Saturday Morning Singles Social Walk!

results.description:
(a set of 4 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is four linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all four classes (Oct 24, 31, Nov. 7 and 14) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the school (left side of the church), enter under the green awning then up two flights to the gym!

The people wanted to find respect and recognition on the world stage, to feel secure and powerful, and to be prosperous and comfortable in their own homes.  But this was at a time when everyone was doing what was right in their own eyes.  Doesn't sound so different from today, does it?  But God wants to show us a better way--a man who will do all his will, a king after God's own heart.

Join us as we investigate the story of 1 Samuel and the different lessons for us!

results.description:
“Great photography is about depth of feeling, not depth of field.”
– Peter Adams


Greetings Photographers! The weather for Saturday looks fantastic so let's go! Last weekend we went to Mount Auburn Cemetery and had a great shoot in nature. I thought we should do something really fun this weekend that will challenge your skills in a different way.

 This is your chance to learn the secrets of how to creatively photograph total strangers on the street. As a special treat, there will be a Halloween Pet Parade Costume Contest. So if you are not ready to photograph people, you can start with the pets. I am sure they will love the attention.

Photographing people, strangers, friends, family, is a skill we should all strive to develop. It is a wonderful part of being a photographer, to be able to capture moment of beauty as people enjoy the simple pleasures of life. I hope you will join us to hone your skill and have some fun. 


Some of the topics I will cover in the workshop will be:

• Timing and positioning so you increase the chances of getting the lucky shot.

• Composition of subjects within the frame and in relationship to each other.

• How to use elements of color, light, texture, and motion to evoke emotion and tell a story. 

• How to simplify the shot so you capture the essence of the moment.

• Some basic camera operation tips will be offered if you need them to freeze the action and catch the moment.

How to get permission for the photo with out destroying the candid feeling.  If you have taken this class with me recently, I will have some new challenges for you so you can continue to improve. 

This special workshop on street photography will introduce you to a step by step method for gaining confidence in photographing people and pets. This is a essential skill for travel photographers, family photographers, and anyone interested in capturing the ordinary moments of life in a way that tells a story.

Photo By Student at previous Street Photography Class. 

Photo By Instructor: Suzanne Merritt Creative composition using fresh viewpoint.

We will start at Quincy Market where there are plenty of people to practice on.  People will be busy shopping, eating, and watching street performers so they will never notice you are photographing them for your class assignments.

Great example of selecting a small detail to tell a story. Photo by Student Doc.

How we will work:

We will meet together in front of the Faneuil Hall building at Quincy Market where I will give a short introduction to the topics and show you sample photos. You will be given specific photo assignments designed to build your skills step by step. I will provide handout cards so you can practice the assignments again after the class.

At the end class there will be social time where we will take a look at the photos of the day and give each other constructive critique. I highly recommend you plan on joining us for this part of the workshop. 

Wonderful eye contact and interaction with the subject. Student Heather C.

Please RSVP right away to hold your spot in this class. The tuition for the workshop is $30.00 I look forward to seeing you on Sunday.

P.S. This class is appropriate for all levels so if you have just joined the group, this would be a perfect place to start. You do need a camera rather than an iPhone for this one so. You will meet like minded people who love photography and you will learn some new skills at the same time. What a great way to spend the afternoon!

Until we meetup again,

Suzanne

results.description:
BOOK:

Faint Promise of Rain by Anjali Mitter Duva

Only 8 copies in the Minuteman Library System.

DESCRIPTION:

It is 1554 in the desert of Rajasthan, and a new Mughal emperor is expanding his territory. On a rare night of rain, a daughter, Adhira, is born to a family of Hindu temple dancers. Fearing a bleak future, her father―against his wife and sons’ protests―puts his faith in tradition and in his last child for each to save the other: he insists Adhira “marry” the temple deity and give herself to a wealthy patron. But after one terrible evening, she makes a bold choice that carries her family’s story and their dance to a startling new beginning. Told from the perspective of this exquisite dancer and filled with the sounds, sights and flavors of the Indian desert, Faint Promise of Rain is the story of a family and a girl caught between art, duty, and fear in a changing world.

AUTHOR:

Anjali Mitter Duva is a writer who grew up in France and has family roots in Calcutta, India. After completing graduate studies at MIT and launching a career in urban planning, she found the call of storytelling too great to resist. A switch to freelance writing and project management allowed her more time for her own creative pursuits. Her first novel, Faint Promise of Rain, came out with She Writes Press in October 2014. She is a co-founder of Chhandika, an organization that teaches and presents India’s classical storytelling kathak dance. Anjali lives near Boston with her husband and two daughters, and is at work on her second novel, set in 19th century Lucknow.

results.name: Faint Promise of Rain by Anjali Mitter Duva at India Pavilion, Cambridge

results.description:
Join us for a monthly meetup to play some 18xx games.

Contact Dave M (click the link, then click "Message") for the address.

For the uninitiated, 18xx games are a subset of train games with a focus on stock-market and tile laying mechanics in the 19th century. Players start-up and manage (or mismanage…) railroads with the winning condition being money in the player’s hands at the end of the game. These games are all long, heavy, and feature little randomness leading many to consider them some of the most rewarding games to play. For more information please visit the wikipedia page at (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18XX_games) or the BGG Wiki page at (https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/18xx). You can find a version of the rules for 1830 on the mayfair website (http://mayfairgames.com/mfg-shop3/rules/MFG1830-Rules-V1_0.pdf) (focus on the 1830 classic rules) if you are interested in getting a head start.

For this meetup, we will try and get somewhere between 2-3 games in over the session. Players of all skill levels are invited to join us and we are happy to teach new players the system as well as teach new games in the system (I am still fairly new to the system myself).

PLEASE NOTE: Since the focus of this meetup is on longer games and the headcount limit is low (5 players/1 table) please be considerate when RSVPing for this event. Please try to give notice to those on the waitlist if you expect to have to drop your RSVP. Additionally, since there is only one table and the games are long, please try to arrive on time, since 1 person late will delay the whole group.

Please contact Dave M (click the link, then click "Message") for the address as well as any other information.
results.name: Monthly 18xx in Waltham

results.description:
I played a great game of Successors yesterday, which whetted my appetite for playing one of the famous GBCC monster games "Here I Stand" or "Virgin Queen."

These games are particular favorites of mine. At their heart, they're strategic wargames but the wargame aspect is surrounded by layers of other ... stuff. Theological debates. Colonization of the New World. Patronizing artists and architects and scientists. There's lots of ways to win, and even more ways to lose. I know people who never thought they'd be into a historical wargame who came away loving it. You don't have to know how to play the games to participate (though you may want to do a little studying before game time). Some experience with card driven games -- Successors, Sword of Rome, Nappy Wars, even Twilight Struggle, will help a little. I'll be there to answer questions. It'll be OK.

So here's the deal: each of these games are best with exactly six players. Virgin Queen is decently playable with five. Here I Stand works OK with three. But we really want to shoot for six.

Here's another deal: the games are very, very long. With relatively inexperienced players, we can start at one in the afternoon and not be surprised to still be playing at nine at night. Srsly. We love you and we totally understand if this is a dealbreaker for you, but if there's a non-trivial chance that you're going to show up and need to leave three (or even five) hours later, this is not the event for you.

Here's another deal: the games really strongly hinge on throwing yourself into the negotiation aspect. This is not a case where simply sitting back and working out a winning strategy with your big ol' brain is going to win the day. You've got to make deals and make friends.

Here's yet another deal: this event, if we pull it off, is probably going to be the last go-round for me and these games for quite a while, at least face-to-face. So I'm really motivated to see if we can pull it off.

If you're interested in theory in this event, please RSVP and talk it up in the comments as to dates you are available in September or October. If you RSVP, there is no obligation to stick with it if the date is one not feasable for you.
results.name: The Analog Reformation (Virgin Queen in Watertown)

results.description:
WHAT: A workshop on telling our own stories through SoulCollage. Whether you're brand-new to SoulCollage or you've already started your SoulCollage deck, this workshop is for you!


If there's interest, we can continue to make SoulCollage cards from 3-5 p.m. (immediately after this workshop).  

WHEN: Saturday, October 24, from 1 to 3 p.m.


WHERE: The Braintree Community Art Center, 1969 Washington St., Braintree, MA 02184. See directions at end.


We'll be in a large, bright, open room on the first floor. The Center has restrooms and free parking. There are restaurants and stores--including a good Michaels--nearby!

WHAT SHOULD I BRING? Everything will be supplied. If cards in progress that you'd like to work on--feel free to bring them. But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine; we'll have plenty to go around. We'll be doing some writing, so if you have a favorite notebook and pen, bring them (if not, I'll supply both). Bring a beverage and a snack, if you like.


COST: $20 per person for the workshop, plus $5 per person for a packet of supplies that you get to keep (total $25). At this writing, BCAC is still setting up its online registration/payment system, so you can pay when you arrive with a check, cash (no coins), or PayPal. Need an ATM? Ask; I live nearby and can direct you to one.  


RSVPs: The RSVP list is our headcount for the day. If you plan to attend, RSVP "yes" so you'll receive all Meetup notifications. If your plans change, switch your RSVP to "no" by 24 hours in advance. If you cancel within 24 hours (or RSVP "yes" and don't show up), you'll need to pay $25 anyway to help cover our costs for the day. You'll receive an extra supply packet next time you attend.

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

DIRECTIONS:

For those who know the area: The BCAC is about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the same road (Route 37). It's a two-story white house with a big sign in the front yard.


--From Route 93: From either direction: Take Exit 6. Turn left off ramp. This is Route 37. Pass mall on left. Follow Route 37 through several intersections (about 3.5 miles) to BCAC on right, just before Holbrook town line. Street name changes several times; just follow signs for Route 37.


--By T: Take the Red Line to Braintree; grab a cab at station (someone else can probably give you a ride back after).

--From Route 3: Exit on Union Street. Pass T station on left. Follow Union to end at Washington Street (facing Thayer Academy). Turn LEFT on Washington, then immediately RIGHT on Central. Follow Central two blocks to end. Turn LEFT on Franklin (Route 37). Follow Route 37 for about 2.5 miles to BCAC on right, just before Holbrook town line. Street name changes several times; just keep following the signs for Route 37.


Really hope to see you there!

results.description:
Hi everyone.  Saturday looks like a perfect day for a walk / hike. World's End is very beautiful  - should be close or at peak foliage.  We should be able to walk for about 2 hours.  After the hike we can grab something to eat or drink close by.

Let's Meet at the entrance near the ranger station. 

About World's End 

Rolling hills and rocky shorelines offer sweeping views of the Boston skyline, while tree-lined carriage paths designed by famed landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted make delightful walking trails.

What makes World’s End a special place? 
We think it’s the tree-lined carriage paths and sweeping views of the Boston skyline, only 15 miles away. The 251-acre coastscape includes rocky shores, broad hillsides, and open fields bracketed by pockets of woodlands. The property is ideal for walking, picnicking, jogging, horseback riding, cross-country skiing, or simply enjoying nature and the outdoors.

http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/greater-boston/worlds-end.html

Please wear shoes made for walking/hiking. Bring water and a light jacket. I suggest that people try and carpool as there is limited parking.

Trails 
4.5 miles of carriage paths and footpaths. Moderate hiking. 

Facilities 
Public restrooms. Benches. Drinking water fountain. 

When to Visit 
Year-round, daily, 8 a.m. to sunset. Allow a minimum of 2 hours. 

Regulations & Advisories 
Dogs must be kept on a leash at all times.

Directions 
Martin’s Lane 
Hingham, MA 02043 
Telephone: Get directions on Google Maps. 

From Rt. 3, take Exit 14, Rt. 228 North for 6.5 mi. Turn left onto Rt. 3A and follow for 0.7 mi. Turn right onto Summer St. and, at major intersection with Rockland St., continue straight across onto Martin’s Lane. Follow for 0.7 mi. to entrance and parking (70 cars) at end. Roadside parking is not permitted.

Admission Fees & Permits 
Trustees members and children free. Nonmember adults: $6.  Parking is free with admission.

Disclaimer From Meetup: 

PLEASE NOTE:  MY ROLE AS A HOST IN THIS HIKE IS SOCIAL. I AM NOT TRAINED TO BE A GUIDE, NOR AM I AN EXPERT IN HIKING SAFETY. YOU WILL NEED TO TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR YOUR OWN COMFORT AND SAFETY.

MOREOVER, THERE IS ALWAYS A RISK OF INJURY IN HIKING. IT IS YOUR RESPONSIBILITY TO BE SURE THAT YOU CAN COMPLETE THE HIKE SAFELY BEFORE JOINING.  FURTHERMORE, YOU WILL NEED TO DETERMINE IF YOU CAN SAFELY CROSS THE TERRAIN ENCOUNTERED DURING THE HIKE.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at ranger entrance

results.description:
{Do you seek greater inner peace?  Peacemakers is a group that helps you look at what "peace" means to you and helps you find how to create more peace in your life.} 

Our Topic This Evening Will ....

... provide you an opportunity to let go of tension, upset, and judgements so that you can experience greater peace.

Many of us have accepted living with tensions in our bodies, with upsets spoiling our mood at unexpected times, with judgments sneaking in. 

Come join us as we practice living our lives more peacefully. 

Peace is not being passive, submissive or indifferent. Peace is an active consciousness that we can learn to enter into, enriching our individual lives, our social situations and the world at large. 

During this evening, we will practice discovering the peace that is always present within us -- no matter what else is going on inside us or outside us in the world.   As we practice recognizing our inner core of peace, we become increasingly able to choose to live in that consciousness of inner peace, even at difficult times of our lives. 

We will look at where we unconsciously practice "against-ness", and learn to let go of that feeling of against-ness, to better work with reality and with the people who surround us. As we let go of "against-ness", we also let go of the upset feelings, prejudices, judgments, tenseness, etc. 

This meeting is sponsored by the Institute of Individual and World Peace (www.iiwp.org)

To Prepare ....

1) When do you feel "against-ness"? 


2) What are the physical signs of your against-ness? (e.g., tightness in throat)  

3) What emotional signs or mental beliefs could be signs of against-ness?

4) How could you be more effective if you were in peace even when bad things happened?

Our Leaders This Evening

https://fbcdn-profile-a.akamaihd.net/hprofile-ak-prn2/v/t1.0-1/c39.0.160.160/p160x160/537349_10152034344599510_1494662630_n.jpg?oh=e6044f0c169d6d3bcd9bce21fb142bbc&oe=5615B058&__gda__=1446013507_b7d9a5381ee0960560099851af0e879a

David Jenkins aspires to live his life more and more in peace. He considers himself a student of living the four principles of peace in his life. This is his highest priority. He is overjoyed to have been involved with the Peacemaker Project for several years. It expands peace in a quiet, loving way, one person at a time.

Emily Page delights in finding joy with others and as an inner process one moment at a time.She's been assisting with Boston Area PeaceMaker Meetings because the simple tools shared go so deep, work so fast and foster such harmony between participants, one session after another. 

Philosophy: The philosophy grounding this work is the realization that peace must start with the individual. One can not fight for peace. If we are going to be a conduit for peace, we must start with ourselves and be in peace. Peace is defined as the absence of againstness. If we can be in peace without being against ourselves or others or situations and encourage others to do the same, then we can be a conduit for peace. 

Facilitators Motivation: We aspire to live our lives more and more in peace. This intention is our highest priority. Participating in these meetings is one way to learn to live our lives more and more in peace. Encouraging others to do the same is strengthening for us all.
results.name: Peacemakers: Create Inner Peace for a Happier Life

results.description:
Yo what's good people?

In a few weeks the Boston Book Festival will be taking place October 23rd and October 24th.  There is a panel occurring on October 24th entitled, "Racial Justice and Community Activism in the Age of Black Lives Matter"

I've been to the panels last year, pretty dope stuff.  

I recommend getting there 15 mins before it starts so you can grab a seat. These joints fill up quite quickly, trust me.  Check out the information below.

This event is free and open to the public!


http://www.bostonbookfest.org/attend/event-descriptions/racial-justice-and-community-activism-in-the-age-of-black-lives-matter/


Join the conversation about black political and social activism with leading scholars of the subject. Peniel Joseph, author of Stokely: A Life, is a founder of a sub-field in Africana studies called Black Power studies. Jason Sokol, author of All Eyes Are Upon Us: Race and Politics from Boston To Brooklyn, specializes in politics, race, and civil rights. Laurence Ralph, author of Renegade Dreams: Living through Injury in Gangland Chicago, studies how police abuse, mass incarceration, and the drug trade normalize disease, disability, and premature death in the inner city. Come participate in this illuminating and timely discussion moderated by Callie Crossley, host of Under the Radar on WGBH Radio.
results.name: Racial Justice and Community Activism in the Age of Black Lives Matter

Bring your own Halloween costume and hack it the way you want it. We will provide wearable technology kits at a reasonable cost and space, tools everything else to assemble it.

Please choose one of four possible activities from below.

1. Are you interested in using electroluminescent (EL) wiring to accent a costume? Difficulty: Advanced (requires good soldering skills and steady hands)

2. Are you interested in making a lighted trick-or-treat bag using conductive thread, a circuit powering LEDs is sewn into a canvas bag to make a unique glowing goodie bag? Difficulty: Beginner

3. Do you want to build a flameless automatic candle? Build a simple circuit that will turn on a LED that flickers just like a real candle. Your "candle" color can be any color from red to blue. Difficulty: Moderate (some soldering required)

4. Are you interested in adding sound effects to your costume. Connect a switch, either pushbutton or motion triggered, to activate a sound recording and playback circuit to play a sound of your choice? Difficulty: Beginner.
results.how_to_find_us: www.creationstationma.com
results.name: Halloween Hackathon

results.description:
There is nothing more wonderful than a nice stroll through Boston on a summer day, that is, unless you add food and wine! 

This fabulous 

2 hour guided walking tour

 stops at fine Boston restaurants and wine stores to teach you how to buy wines, find hidden gems and 

educate you in the fine art of wine tasting and food pairing

. While enjoying your food and wine, you will even learn a bit of Boston history.

This 

Wine & Food Walking Tour 

generally includes:


Tastings of 6 delicious wines, paired up with food.Learning how to taste wine. 

2-3 tour stops

 including a variety of restaurants.A chance to explore Boston's vibrant culture


with a local guide.

Our first stop

 on the tour is Pasta Beach, a classic Italian restaurant, which offers a great wine list and delicious food. This restaurant sits on the cusp of Boston Harbor. 

Our second stop

 is Tamo Bistro & Bar. You will embark on a scenic walk, which takes us up Sea Port Lane to a beautiful hotel. Here we will sample delicious wine and food pairings while enjoying views of the harbor.

Our third stop

 is either Salvatore's, or J Pace Wine Shop. This stop takes us further up the sea port where we learn how to pair wine with Italian dishes.

Learn how to taste, pour and pair wine, join us today for a memorable tour!
results.name: Water front wine tour

The Foodicine Health Cooking Series For "Special Diets"
www.foodicinehealth.org

OCTOBER 24,[masked]:00-5:00 pm
Seaport Hotel Boston Action Kitchen

YES, YOU CAN EAT GOURMET FOR HEART, KIDNEY, KIDNEY STONES, AND BLOOD PRESSURE HEALTH

Low-Salt Meals That Wow! Learn How to Flavor Foods With Little Salt

Chef-William Kovel, Catalyst Restaurant, Boston, MA
Dietitian-Elizabeth Moore, Nutrition Center, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston, MA There is a charge for this event-To Buy Tickets Go To:
http://www.eventbrite.com/o/foodicine-health-inc-8383710024


Have you been diagnosed with a chronic illness or a food allergy and think that your diet is now destined to be limited or boring? Are you unsure of what you can or cannot eat on your low-carbohydrate/low-sugar, low-fat, low-salt, gluten-free or other “Special Diet” and are looking for ways to eat fabulous, yummy food? Do you just want to learn new cooking techniques or new recipes that include ingredients that your physician or dietitian has told you are included on your prescribed diet? Then the Foodicine Health “Yes, You Can Eat!” Cooking Series is for you! Join expert Dietitians and Celebrity Chefs as they discuss ways to change your lifestyle and diet to help you to improve your health AND cook delicious meals that fit into your dietary requirements, are fun and easy to prepare, and will delight your friends and family.

Each class will focus on a different “Special Diet” that is associated with a different chronic illness or food allergy. You can taste the recipes that the Chefs are cooking and will leave these classes with dietary information regarding your specific medical condition or allergy and with recipes that you will love to prepare at home! You will also learn that your future is destined to be gourmet, fun and delicious.
results.name: CELEBRITY CHEF COOKING SERIES-LOW-SALT COOKING FOR HEART AND KIDNEY HEALTH

results.description:
Update! Screening time is confirmed for 4.15pm.

Get Tickets


Both highly suspenseful and deeply emotional, Room is a unique and unexpectedly tender exploration of the boundless love between a mother and her child under the most harrowing of circumstances.

Room tells the extraordinary story of Jack, a spirited 5-year-old who is looked after by his loving and devoted Ma. Like any good mother, Ma dedicates herself to keeping Jack happy and safe, nurturing him with warmth and love and doing typical things like playing games and telling stories.

Their life, however, is anything but typical - they are trapped - confined to a windowless, 10-by-10-foot space, which Ma has euphemistically named "Room." Ma has created a whole universe for Jack within Room, and she will stop at nothing to ensure that, even in this treacherous environment, Jack is able to live a complete and fulfilling life. But as Jack's curiosity about their situation grows, and Ma's resilience reaches its breaking point, they enact a risky plan to escape, ultimately bringing them face-to-face with what may turn out to be the scariest thing yet: the real world.

The march actually starts at 4PM at South Station and heads downtown over the course of the next 4 hours. Sunset is 5:49.

Shooting on the fly will be the best strategy here. Use fast lenses and high ISOs. Get up close and personal for the most interesting shots.

results.description:
Let's meet up at the EcoTarium for the Great Pumpkin Fest and see hundreds of pumpkins along the EcoTarium paths as well as play in the museum!  We'll meet at the big sundial in front of the museum at 5:30 pm. The Great Pumpkin Fest starts at 2 pm, but to accommodate kids with afternoon nap times as well as driving times, let's meet at 5:30 pm.  You *are* allowed to bring your own food (or purchase snacks there), so the overlap with dinnertime can be accommodated.  For more information about the the Great Pumpkin Fest or the EcoTarium, please visit: http://www.ecotarium.org/events-activities/great-pumpkin-fest  

(Note: This is a rain-or-shine event.  Be sure to bring your own flashlights and decent walking shoes to navigate the outdoor paths.)
results.name: Let's see LOTS of pumpkins at the EcoTarium, Sat. 10/24 at 5:30 pm

results.description:
We will practice together, play and study theory.

Usually we get quite a few beginners, so if you are just starting don't be shy, you definitely can join us. If you have been playing for some time I am sure you will find a few helpful ideas as well. If the level will be very different then we might divide it to two groups eventually.

Half of the class time is dedicated to a consecutive curriculum. I try to choose themes that are relevant to everybody in the class. We might talk about some aspects of technique, or reading, or theory etc. The other half of the class time I usually help students with their individual issues and questions.

I see this class as a supportive and motivational environment for your self-teaching process.

This is PAY-WHAT-YOU-WANT class. We kindly ask you to support your teacher and Westland Guitars that provided the space.
results.how_to_find_us: Westland Guitars is quite easy to find, I believe. For those of you who are familiar with the area it is very close to Whole Foods (across the street) and Symphony Hall. 54B is in the basement and it has its own dedicated entrance.

Oh, and by the way, we'll also be providing a drink ticket (good until 8:30) for you. Good for one refreshing and ice-cold spirit to quench your thirst. Complimentary! :) 


What a Hassle-free way to meet new people who share your values.

Josh and friends

results.description:
Hey fellow 20's and 30's, 


Do you want to meet new people who share your values? 
Do you want easily meet interesting new people? 
What's our celebration going to be like (see pictures) 

Join us for our popular Mix & Mingle celebration. The purpose of this Meetup is for you to meet people who are different from you. Discover new communities. 
Discover who else is coming. 

For this event we will be joining one of Boston's most popular nonprofits. 
Learn more:  Boston Volunteers

Space is very limited b/c the room is small. This event will fill up very soon. We'll get lots of the regulars and lots of new members. 

A couple other groups will be joining us including: 

Don't you like adventure: BBoston Adventures

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

We will be providing lots and lots of food for you. We will serve the food at close to 7:30, so don't miss it! 

Please bring a 10 bill with you to help cover our costs for the event, Meetup costs, and to provide more volunteer events for you in the future. Please bring a 10. There will be a long line, and we want to keep it moving fast. 


Oh, and by the way, we'll also be providing a drink ticket (good until 8:30) for you. Good for one refreshing and ice-cold spirit to quench your thirst. Complimentary! :) 


What a Hassle-free way to meet new people who share your values. 

We hope you can join us, :) 
Josh and friends

results.description:
The High Line in New York is an ex-elevated train line, which was converted to a pedestrian zone. It offers a variety of interesting views. Here is an article about it by the National Geographic.


We will walk down the High Line and start at the newly opened northern section between 34th and 30th street, which leads across the train depot, but there are other interesting views further south as well. We are unsure if the High Line is officially "closed" at night, but I suspect that we can at least roam until 9 pm, if not longer.
In case we need to leave, there is a plethora of cool buildings along Rt 9A, the main stretch down the river.

Bring a variety of lenses, as we will have options to shoot wide and zoom in on cool views, this is an elevated vantage point. Also bring good foot wear, this is an extended walk.


Following are some images from Flickr and you can follow this link for more night photos.
results.name: New York City 3: The Highline

results.description:
Listen to tales of some very strange characters as you explore one of Beverly's oldest houses. Explore the extraordinary Hale House and its connection to the Salem witchcraft hysteria in a guided candlelight tour.


John Hale played a prominent role in the 1692 Salem witchcraft trials, and his children were threatened with witchcraft by a family servant who was an habitual thief. Hale wrote a book that was written at Hale Farm and published posthumously, "A Modest Inquiry Into the Nature of Witchcraft."

$11.34


You must purchase tickets ahead of time by clicking here.  Be sure to register for the 7:00 event.
results.name: Witch Stories by Candlelight

results.description:
We have such a wonderful time at this amazing tribute that it has become a yearly tradition.

John Coltrane inspired many, no matter the community or culture, to achieve musical, spiritual, and humanitarian heights never thought possible.

The Friends of John Coltrane Memorial Concert (fJCMC) in collaboration with the Northeastern Center for the Arts present the 2015 John Coltrane Memorial Concert.

An ensemble of master jazz musicians pays tribute to two giants, John Coltrane and Ornette Coleman, at the 38th Annual John Coltrane Memorial Concert. These two innovators shared a deep kinship through their music as they pushed the boundaries of what jazz music could be with the free jazz movement of the '60s.

The John Coltrane Memorial Ensemble consisting of Carl Atkins, Leonard Brown, Billy Buss, Jeff Galindo, Laszlo Gardony, Yoron Israel, John Lockwood, Jason Palmer, Rick Stepton, Stan Strickland and Bobby Tynes perform and WGBH radio's Eric Jackson hosts.

Doors open at 7:00 PM

Concert begins at 7:30 PM 

General Admission: $30
Students & Seniors: $25
VIP: $40

Ticket prices include service charge.
Use code FJCMC10 for 10% off general admission. Good through 10/13/2015.

Buy on line here, http://neu.universitytickets.com/user_pages/event.aspx?id=1633&cid=142&p=1

Act quickly for GoldStar's $19.75 ticket deal at this link,  http://www.goldstar.com/events/boston-ma/38th-annual-john-coltrane-memorial-concert-tickets

Act quickly for Bostix $23.25 discount tickets at this link, https://ticketforce.bostix.org/eventperformances.asp?evt=1432

Please let me know if you want to meet around 5:30 PM to eat at either

Uno Pizza 280 Huntington Ave 02115

                       or

Panera Bread 289 Huntington Ave 02115.

Both Uno and Panera are a block from Ell Hall in which Blackman Theatre is located.

MBTA:

Check out MBTA or Hop Stop to plan your public transportation route.

Ruggles subway station - Orange Line

Northeastern subway station (E train)  - Green Line

DRIVING DIRECTIONS:

Check out Google to plan your route.

PARKING:

Check out Best Parking for nearby garages and lots.
results.how_to_find_us: At 6:45 pm meet at the bronze statue of a dog (Northestern's Husky mascot) in the lobby of Ell Hall
results.name: 38th Annual John Coltrane Memorial Concert - ORNETTE ‘N ‘TRANE

results.description:
Join us for a high energy, fun evening to celebrate drumming, community, dance. Fine for beginners as well as experts. We're in a great space with lots of room for dancers - so come and try both drumming and dance if you wish. Bring friends, extra drums to share, maybe some snacks. MINI-CLASS at 6:30 sharp. A good introduction for beginners, and a tune-up for experts.

Admission $10   children under 12 Free

If you never drummed - welcome - we make it easy, and have drums to share.

Please log in to meetup group and "RSVP" so we know how many are coming, and how many drums to bring.

If you have NOT filled out the "bio" questions, please do so by logging in at Meetup group and editing the "profile", where you can let us know if you have a drum, or need one.

THANKS!!

John Alan Chris Thierno Lillian Joel and all of us . . .


PHOTO  -   One of the visiting Masters from West Africa, Billy Nankouma Konate, who has been sharing traditions and spirit and rhythms over the past two weeks.  We will bring some of that amazing energy and celebration to the circle this Saturday.

Whatever your experience or musical "skill" you will feel at home in this community.

Drumming in community is many things . . from inner, healing energy, to intense celebration.  Each evening is a bit different, but always you leave changed, and some of daily life and stress drops away.
results.how_to_find_us: Entrance is from parking lot behind the church. If lost call me at 617-967-2962  - John Tracy
results.name: Framingham Drum Circle

results.description:
Anderson Comedy is proud to present a special Saturday show at Great Scott featuring Jared Logan and Kara Klenk!

Jared appeared in his own half hour stand-up special on Comedy Central You can see him every week as a cast member on VH1’s Best Week Ever. He’s been featured on TBS's The Pete Holmes Show and Comedy Central's The Meltdown. He was a delegate for Comedy Central's Indecision 2012. Check out his web series Don't You Think on YouTube. Jared lives in New York but is originally from West Virginia. He belongs to one of the few mountain clans who did not handle snakes or make moonshine. Kara is a stand up comic, writer, improviser and actor based in New York City. Recently named by Time Out New York as one of the Top 10 Funniest Women in NYC, Kara has appeared on Comedy Central, TruTV, Oxygen, SpikeTV, Nickelodeon, Hallmark Channel, Food Network, TVGuide Network, Current TV, Biography, HLN, Comedy Central's Atom.com, CollegeHumor.com, AdultSwim.com, and MTV.com.

18+ $5 hosted by Rob Crean

https://www.facebook.com/events/443144412538083/

Tickets here: http://www.ticketmaster.com/event/01004F4CF65F688F

Five-time Grammy & Academy Award winner, BJ Thomas is a true American institution. His iconic pop, country and gospel hits have defined and transcended their generations.

BJ has sold more than 70 million records and is ranked in Billboard’s Top 50 most played artists over the past 50 years. Hits include: Raindrops Keep Fallin’ on my Head, I’m So Lonesome I Could Cry, Hooked on a Feeling, I Just Can't Help Believing, & (Hey Won't You Play) Another Somebody Done Somebody Wrong Song.

Tickets are $40 and benefit The Boys & Girls Club of Greater Salem.

Buy tickets here:  http://thecabot.org/event.cfm?id=209532&cart

We'll meet in the lobby a half hour before the concert.
