results.description:
notloB Music's Fall music series continues at the intimate (50 seat) cafe at the Somerville Armory, presenting in a return engagement (5/26/15), Roy Williams, this time accompanied by Eddie Barbash.
http://www.roywilliamsplaysmusic.com/

Roy Williams, an American songwriter, guitarist, and multi-instrumentalist, writes music with a curious ear and an open mind. From the classic pop tunes heard on the first cassette Roy owned—The Beatles “Live at the BBC in 1963”—to the incomparable instrumental canon of Django Reinhart, Roy’s influences eclipse genre categorization, a trait that is reflected in the adventurous spirit of his own original songs.


After growing up in Clark’s Green, Pennsylvania, in a musical house where Neil Young, Buffalo Springfield, and especially The Beatles were religion, Roy began playing gigs in nearby Scranton and soon moved to New York City to perform gypsy jazz with renowned guitarist Stephane Wrembel. Roy worked with Wrembel for four years and toured throughout Central America, Asia, Africa, and Europe. He now lives in Brooklyn, New York, where he regularly plays out with his mentors and friends Jim Campilongo, Nick Driscoll, and Alex Hargreaves, and leads his own band.

Roy often performs on piano, mandolin, bass, and has known how to play a G chord on guitar since he can remember. He released his debut solo album, Throwing Punches, in February 2015, which features ten original compositions. Roy is currently at work on two upcoming albums: a compilation of instrumental songs by his group Roy Williams and the Human Hands (featuring Alex Hargreaves and Nick Driscoll), and a solo record of rock n roll tunes.

Eddie Barbash plays American roots music on alto saxophone. He brings his horn and sensibility to Texas and Appalachian fiddle tunes, bluegrass, old time, R&B, soul, and jazz. His pioneering take on these traditions has attracted audiences around the world. He is a founding member and the lyrical core of Jon Batiste and Stay Human, currently the house band for The Late Show With Stephen Colbert. He was raised in Oaxaca, Mexico, Atlanta, Georgia and Winston-Salem, North Carolina. He lives in Brooklyn.
http://eddiebarbash.com/

As we did at our Loring-Greenough concert series, admission is by free-will donation, $10-20 suggested.

As this is a small space, reservations via Eventbrite are strongly suggested - http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315 - or directly at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/roy-williams-and-the-human-hands-tickets-18976924492

The cafe serves soup, sandwiches, desserts, coffee, tea beer and wine.
Free parking (44 spaces) in the back lot and on street*
MBTA: Arts at the Armory is approximately a 15 minute walk from Davis Square which is on the MBTA Red Line. You can also find us by using either the MBTA RT 88 and RT 90 bus that can be caught either at Lechmere (Green Line) or Davis Square (Red Line). Get off at the Highland Avenue and Lowell Street stop. You can also get there from Sullivan Square (Orange Line) by using the MBTA RT 90 bus. Get off at the Highland Avenue and Benton Road stop.
Bicycle: The Armory is four blocks (down Lowell Street) from the Somerville Community Path.
More info at http://artsatthearmory.org/about/getting-here/

BE SOCIAL, SHARE THIS FACEBOOK EVENT - https://www.facebook.com/events/1633339643582629/

==============
* Armory parking alert!
When concerts are presented in the large space (we're in the cafe), parking can be problematic. Check the Armory's calendar, as big concerts can be added or canceled at the last minute.
Because the 44-space parking lot fills quickly, make a contingency plan. Recommend the T, walking from the red line or biking from the bike path. See http://artsatthearmory.org/about/getting-here/

=============
Founded in 2007, notloB Music has presented more than 150 folk, old-time, blue grass, string band and Celtic concerts in unique venues throughout the greater Boston area.
STAY IN TOUCH!
Website https://sites.google.com/site/notlobmusic
Tickets/reservations: http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315.
Mail Chimp (mailing list) - http://tinyurl.com/notlobmail
Contact: [masked] - please DO NOT contact the venue.
Subscribe to notloB's Facebook "events": https://www.facebook.com/notloBParlourConcerts/events
results.how_to_find_us: Ask at the door for Jeff.
results.name: Roy Williams and Eddie Barbash play The Human Hands Songbook

results.description:
It's that time of year again. The ghosts, goblins, and racists come out to play for Halloween. For our October social we're providing a fun and festive party that's free of the -ism (racism, colonialism, xenophobia, sexism, etc) based costumes. Light food and one holiday themed cocktail will be made available, but please add to the party with something to share-food, alcoholic or non-alcoholic beverage. 

Healthy and non-cultural appropriation costumes are encouraged (and required if dressing up), but you can happily attend sans costume. 

Access Information:

Jen's house is not wheelchair accessible. There is a small flight of stairs to get on the porch. The apartment is on the 1st floor and free of animals and cigarette smoke. 

Please read (and share) the following articles before the party and before you choose a Halloween costume:

  http://nativeappropriations.com/2013/10/the-one-stop-for-all-your-indian-costumes-are-racist-needs.html

http://everydayfeminism.com/2013/10/is-your-halloween-costume-racist/

This one is a wonderful resource about how to personally address racism in Halloween costumes. It can be applied for someone who dresses up as any race. http://nativeappropriations.com/2013/10/so-your-friend-dressed-up-as-an-indian-now-what.html

http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/11/05/model-wearing-most-disgusting-native-american-halloween-costume-ever-157702
results.name: October Social: A Non-ism based Halloween

Who won the World Series last year? Know one cares! Who won BOSTON A-Lists Best Night of Comedy? THE MENDOZA LINE!
This and every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you a different lineup stacked with the biggest, baddest, and bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. And guess the funk what? Its only FIVE DOLLARS! With drink specials as far as the eye can see and free popcorn, this intimate atmosphere is the perfect place to take in some meaningful and quality laughs!

ANDREW MAYER (album "Nonsense" just released)

PAMELA ROSS (Pavement Comedy Night)

SHAUN BEDGOOD (Comedy Central's Up Next)

ZACH NORTON (author of some weird fan fiction, we assume) OWEN LINDERS (Thunderbar Comedy)

GARY PETERSEN (Opened for Louis CK)

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.
results.name: Volunteer and serve breakfast at the New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
On our ride last weekend, several folks wanted to know if we could squeeze one more ride in. Brian suggested this meetup before .  

If you haven't been to the Vanilla Bean before, it is a great place. The Vanilla Bean is cafe that has ample indoor seating and outside seating as needed. The scenery along the route is nice rolling hills and back roads. Lots of bikers hit visit "The Bean" so you will feel welcome with this crowd. The food is good and the deserts are delicious. Note: The parking lot is packed crushed stone so bring a kickstand coaster.


We'll pass the Wachusett and South Charleston Reservoir and if folks are up for it, visit the Quabbin. Let's gather at 7:30AM and kickstands up at 8:00 Sharp. Please arrive with a full tank of gas.... Hope to see everyone!
results.name: CT Foliage Ride and  Vanilla Bean Cafe - Rescheduled

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to four of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Monroe, Eisenhower, Pierce, and Jackson. We will use Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail to reach the ridge and then we will follow Mount Monroe Loop and Crawford Path, Webster Cliff Trail, and Webster Jackson Trail to climb over each of the summits. There will be a few steep sections on the way up to Monroe and then we will be above treeline until we reach Eisenhower. The Madison Spring Hut is already closed for the season and the Mizpah Hut closes on October 17th.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 12.6 miles and climb about 4,700 feet. It should take an average hiker about 8 hours 45 minutes to complete. This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/4-Mt-Monroe-5384


http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/11-Mt-Eisenhower-4780--27-Mt-Pierce-4310


http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/38-Mt-Jackson-4052


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.32544431762692&lat=44.25394950858018#.ViAquLTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


IT'S WINTER IN THE MOUNTAINS - WINTER CLOTHING AND GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS HIKE. DON'T THINK WE WILL NEED SNOWSHOES BUT WINTER BOOTS, TRACTION, AND WEATHER APPROPRIATE CLOTHING IS REQUIRED. EXPERIENCE IN WINTER IS ALSO REQUIRED.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike: 

</a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Webster Jackson Trailhead which is located on the south side of Route 302 about a half mile south of the AMC's Highland Center. According to Google Maps this spot is about 160 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 42 minutes to drive there. Since that is where we will end our trip we will leave a few cars there and drive to the start.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/D8E8SgFqMat


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/
results.name: Couch to 5K Autumn Edition- Week 9

results.description:
For the price of a pair of binoculars and a morning’s walk, bird watching offers many insights into the natural world. This educational walk, hosted by Andrea Golden, will teach participants how to identify birds, where to look for them, and what birds one can expect to see at different times of the year. After a brief discussion at the Farm, we’ll explore the ponds and woods around the Farm as well as in the adjoining conservation areas (Locke Pond and Whipple Hill). This small area provides a variety of habitats throughout the year for different birds, including ducks, herons, woodpeckers and songbirds. Bring binoculars if you have them, and dress for the weather. No dogs, please.

Tuition is $10 per person. Workshop is hosted by Wright-Locke Farm. Registration via wlfarm.org is REQUIRED (option to pay the day of the event is available).

CLICK HERE TO REGISTER: https://www.wlfarm.org/get-involved?page=CiviCRM&q=civicrm/event/register&reset=1&id=196
results.name: Introduction to Bird Watching Walk

results.description:
Meet to paint the model for a four week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $65, non-members for $75.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $65 or $75 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

For information only. This is not a Vegan Metro West Network organized event.

Boston Vegetarian Society proudly presents the

20th Annual Boston Vegetarian Food Festival !!!

Saturday, October 24, 2015, *11AM-6PM and 

Sunday, October 25, 2015, 10AM-4PM

FREE ADMISSION and FREE PARKING!  

*Saturday 10AM-11AM preview.   A limited number of tickets ($5) will be available to visit the Exhibitor Room before the doors open at 11AM for Free  Admission to all.

Reggie Lewis Athletic Center 1350 Tremont Street,

Boston, Massachusetts Subway stop across the street.

This Festival brings together an amazing array of vegetarian natural food providers, top national speakers and chefs, and educational exhibitors in a fun and welcoming environment.

It is a chance to talk directly to food producers, learn the newest items in the marketplace, taste free food samples, shop at show special discounts, or simply learn what vegetarian foods are available and where you can find them! Whether you are a longtime vegetarian or vegan, or someone simply wanting to add more healthy and delicious foods to your meal repertoire, or if you are just curious what it's all about, you are welcome here!

Free admission, Free food sampling, Free speaker presentations, Free parking and a T stop across the street.

You also can learn of ways to benefit the environment, help animals, and enhance your health and well being. There are activities for kids, too!

Learn more about the Festival and the speaker line up:

http://www.bostonveg.org/foodfest/index.html

results.description:
Let's meet up at the Franklin Park Zoo for Zoo Howl and let your little ones trick-or-treat among the animals!  We'll meet in front of admissions at 10 am (see below for more specifics on where to meet).  Zoo Howl starts at 11 am, but to accommodate kids with afternoon nap times, let's meet an hour early to see what we can before the real fun begins.  For more information about Zoo Howl or the Franklin Park Zoo, please visit: http://www.zoonewengland.org/engage/zoo-howl

Where to meet: Park near the Zebra Entrance (1 Franklin Park Rd.) and go toward the two arched columns leading to the ticket booths.  We will meet at the last bench to the left side of the left arch (walking toward the ticket booths).  See  for a map, with the Zebra Entrance pictured to the left.

(Note: Consider bringing a packable umbrella, as brief showers are forecast for Sunday morning.)
results.name: Let's trick-or-treat at Franklin Park Zoo, Sun. 10/25 at 10 am

results.description:
We will be working through Meyer text on the Dussack.  We will also look at how these techniques apply to  One-handed or arming sword.

We are going to interpret Joachim Meyer’s Dussak.  The translation we will use is in

The Art of Combat: A German Martial Arts Treatise of 1570 (Hardcover)

http://www.amazon.com/gp/offer-listing/1848327781/ref=sr_1_5_twi_2_har_olp?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1434813702&sr=1-5&keywords=meyer

with additional material from Meyer’s 1560 work

https://sites.google.com/site/jochimmeyer1560/home/Meyer_1560_english_Maurer_2012.pdf?attredirects=0&d=1

From Jakob Sutor’s “New Illustrated Fechtbuch” of 1612

https://docs.google.com/file/d/0Bxqzt-jcOCFsT19Xa1Q2QXltWm8/edit

Finally some from

Cod.Guelf.83.4 Aug.8º


http://www.thearma.org/Manuals/Codex-Guelf-83.4-Aug-8f-translation.pdf
results.name: Dussack, One-handed sword, Interpreting Meyer Dussack

We are Arabic learners with intermediate to advanced level skills in MSA interested in reading and speaking Levantine spoken Arabic as well as continuing to improve our abilities in Modern Standard Arabic.

We use the book "Syrian Colloquial Arabic"; we suggest that you print up chapters 1 and 2 from this website - http://special.worldofislam.info/index.php?page=syr_ar and bring them to class.

If you wish to buy this book, it can be purchased on-line at the following website - http://www.syrianarabic.com. It will be delivered to you via email as a PDF with MP3 files.  (It is not possible to order it from Amazon or buy it in a bricks-and-mortar store.)   

Looking forward to meeting you - ma'a salaame!!

results.description:
THE POWER OF PRAYER

a Buddhist understanding of the power of the mind

SUNDAY | OCT 25th 


11:00am - 5:00pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis

Do you ever feel stuck, stagnant, or unable to get over a challenge?  How can an understanding of the mind help to shift our life for the better? Come and enjoy this special, in-depth day course about overcoming rigidity in our life and ways of being. Buddhist meditation offers a host of tools to unlock static stages of life.

Through harnessing the vast power of our mind, by focusing it on beneficial wishes and by connecting with the inspiring energy of holy beings, our entire life can transform. In this course, we will explore specific, time-tested methods for how we can start or continue this process in our life, and ultimately unleash our untapped potential for enlightenment.

Everyone welcome - no experience necessary! 

Workshop will consist of 4 sessions with an hour long lunch break in the middle. Light snacks provided.

Cost | $25  / $15 students & seniors. 

Please click here to register.  Seating is limited!

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
Join us for a spooktacular day of fun the Sunday before Halloween! Parents, bring your children to trick-or-treat at over 50 participating stores and restaurants. Other activities include face painting, magic shows, cookie decorating, and activity stations provided by: NECCO, New England Aquarium, Museum of Science, Mary Baker Eddy Library, The Freedom Trail Foundation, and more!

Our nonprofit partner this year is Room to Grow, whose mission is to enrich the lives of babies born into poverty. Room to Grow organizes appointments for parents to receive developmental information, customized support, and all of the needed baby items to ensure a healthy and secure start for their child.

PRU BOO is sponsored by NECCO, making delicious candies since 1847.

WHERE IS IT?
The Shops at Prudential Center, Center-wide! Activities will take place throughout the Center on the day of the event, so wear your walking shoes and wander around to experience all the spooky fun!

WHEN IS IT?
Sunday, October 25
11:00 AM-1:00 PM: Trick-or-Treating sponsored by NECCO
1:30 PM: Kids Concert with Vanessa Trien (South Garden-Weather Permitting)

HOW DO I PARTICIPATE?
For a $4 donation to our nonprofit partner, Room to Grow, your child gets a trick-or-treat bag to use for collecting candy at participating stores. You can purchase a bag starting October 1st at the Customer Service Desk and beat the crowd, or come early on the day of the event as bag sales start at 9:00 AM. Visit the check-in area in Center Court to make your donation, get a trick-or-treat bag and pick up a map of activities.

Activities include:
-Trick-or-Treat (11:00 AM-1:00 PM)
-Face Painting
-Magic Shows
-Cookie Decorating
-Kids Concert with Vanessa Trien
-Children's activities presented by NECCO, New England Aquarium, Museum of Science, The Freedom Trail Foundation, and more!

PARKING?
Parking for the day will be $16. Pick up a discounted parking pass on the day of the event at one of the check-in stations.

results.description:
I'm still new to the Boston area and would LOVE to visit Salem with fellow TrollX-ers. 

I worked out some kinks (ie: meeting places, trains, etc).

I will be taking the train from North Station to Salem at 11:30 a.m. (Train Number 2153). We can meet up on the train. I'll try to wear something that stands out and update on the day of so keep an eye out! This is the train we will be taking. If you're late and/or miss the train, we're not waiting for you. Either find another way to catch up with us or learn to get places on time (now I hope I'm not late...).

When we arrive in Salem, we can go to the Ugly Mug Diner for lunch (Thanks to Mel for that suggestion!) and since this group is dwindling down, we can kind of make up plans as we go along after that. 

I did a little research and I'm open to any witch related museum (Salem Witch Museum, Witch Dungeon Museum, Witch House, etc) and maybe a little shopping and just general walking around.

After that, I don't want this event to be too much of an imposition on your day, we can either take the 3:24 p.m. (Train Number 2156) OR 5:50 p.m. (2108) depending on how long this all takes. (3:24 sounds really early and 5:50 sounds kind of late, doesn't it?) 

If the closer we get to the day and more people are un-RSVP-ing, I will probably cancel the event all together. :( Until another day!

results.description:
Massive Bowling

Pool/Skeeball/Shuffleboard

Extravaganza!

Hey everyone!

It's time again for our big monthly bowling event at Kings! We always have a great time and we always pack the place. If you've attended before, you know THIS EVENT IS AWESOME, RIGHT?! Of course you do!

FAQ:

Q: Is this really free?
A: Yes! It's really free!

- Free Bowling! 
- Free Shoe Rentals! 
- Free Pool! 
- Free Skeeball! 
- Free Shuffleboard!

Q: Can I bring my kids?
A: Yes! Kids are welcome! I usually have lanes 1 & 2 set up with bumpers for them.

Q: What's the best way to get there?
A: Honestly, taking the T is. See the Getting There section below.

Q: C'mon, this is really all free? What's the catch?
A: Yes, it's really all free and there is no catch! Simply put, I'm awesome. lol : )

RSVP now!

RSVP ETIQUETTE

1. This is a really popular event, and we do count the RSVP's for this, so please RSVP in one group only, as this allows for an accurate count and staff is hired according to this number.

2. RSVP RESPONSIBLY! There are many people in the habit of no-showing and it hurts these events! Don't be that person! Only RSVP if you can go and update your RSVP if you can't make it. You fellow group members and organizers are counting on you to show up. : )

❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤

Get ready for a great time with Boston's best socialites!

See you there… :)

~Matt

P.S. We have the entire Royal Room and bowling lanes 1-10 for this event! Find us inside!

❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤

Getting There:

Taking The T: You can get off at the Hynes Convention Center on the B, C, & D Green Line trains and walk the 2 blocks over, or you can get off at the Prudential Mall station on the E Green Line train and walk through the Pru and the Sheraton to get there.

Driving: Parking can be tough and expensive. There is a garage right next door, but it's $29. You can find on street parking, but that's tough on Sunday mornings. If you want to drive and park, I suggest you get to the area 30-45 minutes early and start looking. Newbury, Hereford, Boylston, and Scotia Streets are all places I look and find parking.

FAQs

You can either take the red line to the Central Square stop, and find us on Mass Ave and Prospect St., or you can park in Lot 5 on Bishop Allen Dr., right behind H-Mart.

-Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?

At [masked]!

Either a printed ticket, or an up-to-date ID with your full name.

All tickets can be fully refunded before the event, up to 24 hours prior. Tickets can be 50% refunded in between the 24 hour mark and the day of the event, and no refunds can be made at the beginning of the event.

Tickets can not be refunded during or after the event.

results.description:
Let's drink inside the box while armchair quarterbacking. 

While there clearly are not as many boxed wines in the market as bottled wines, there are still many wonderful boxed wines to sample. We will creatively blind taste several boxed wines and reveal their identity during half time. 

If you are not an American football fanatic, no worries, we have lots of fun wines to taste and compare:

1. White blend, Southern Italy
2. White blend, France, Languedoc
3. Sauvignon Blanc, Chile
4. White blend, Southeast Spain
5. Chardonnay, California, Napa
6. Rose, France, Côtes du Rhône
7. Pinot Noir, Australia
8. Cabernet Sauvignon, Central Italy, IGT
9. Red Blend, France, Côtes du Rhône
10. Malbec, Argentina

NOTE: a Word document of all wines and known details has been created and will be available at the event if you'd like a copy.

Event details:

• Please contribute $10 toward the wines which will be purchased by the host.

• Bring food/appetizer to share that you enjoy eating while watching football and drinking wine. 

• Bring at least one wine glass (two might be better). Depends on how you'd like to taste the wines, but at least one for reds and one for whites is just a suggestion.


• Sarah has 3 TVs with DirecTv Sunday Ticket. This means we will show the Patriots game on the 65" TV in a rather small living room, but will display all other active games on the other two TVs in a grid format if the group desires. If it's an all Patriots crowd then we will just display that game with audio filling the apartment.

• There will be enough places for everyone to sit and watch football if desired.

• Just for fun, there will be corn hole/toss/bags available to play in the expansive nearly empty attic.

• Football jerseys from any team are welcomed.
results.name: Box Wine and Football

results.description:
The Vietnamese class for adults repeats on Sundays and takes place on the second floor of the VietAID Center near the Fields Corner T stop. Parking is also available.

NO NEW STUDENTS (unless you already know some Vietnamese)

Trimester 1: Class 4
Book 1: Lesson 3
Introductions

The school year is divided into 3 trimesters of about 10 weeks each (not including holiday weekends). Students can sign up for 1, 2, or hopefully all 3. Fee for each trimester is $60 and you pay as you go for the trimester(s) that you take. The fee helps pay for space rental, books, printings, snacks, and other miscellaneous items that will be purchased for the class. Pay during your first class, you don't have to pay before. The teacher is southern Vietnamese but he will teach in the northern dialect. The southern pronounce certain letters (d, g, v) the same, which makes it more difficult to learn to read.

There is no homework, no tests. There is only lecture, workshop, practice, and recitation
results.name: Vietnamese Language Class for Adults 4

results.description:
Please join me in supporting My Brother's Table, to honor my daughter's memory.

In loving memory of Daria Elise Pearlman

Our 34th Annual Walk is Sunday, October 25, 2015
Registration at 1 PM, Walk Begins at 1:30 PM


** Bertuccis will be providing pizza at the end of the walk.

** If anyone wants to travel together, let's meet at REI at 11:45am. Carpooling may make good sense all 'round. Please post a message indicating your interest.

Our annual Walk takes place along 3 miles of the scenic Lynn and Swampscott shore, the last Sunday of October. The Walk begins at the Church of the Holy Name, 60 Monument Avenue in Swampscott.

My beloved daughter, Daria Elise, volunteered at My Brother's Table until the very day she passed away in December 2014. She cared very deeply about this program, which provides daily meals to the homeless and underprivileged citizens of Lynn, MA.

Will you please consider helping me to honor her memory by walking alongside me, or if you cannot make it, donating to this Walk, and sponsoring me?

As always, my love and gratitude for your compassion, generosity and support, and friendship.

Jill

For more information about making a donation please visit the following link:

https://mbt.myetap.org/fundraiser/walk2015/individual.do?etapCacheBuster=1443976216573&participationRef=1045.0.134470685&shareMedium=label.facebook


* If you'd rather pay by check, please send me a Meetup message, or post a comment here on the page.

results.description:
GET READY TO HAVE A HOWLING GOOD TIME!! 

Bring your little Puggie hobgoblins to our tenth annual HOWL-O-WEEN BASH!!  Join us and all your little Puggie friends at Assistant Organizer Sharon's home in Carver for the festivities.  Start planning those costumes!

This year's Halloween Social willing be missing one of our favorite participants, Sharon's Pug Buford, who is no longer with us.   We miss you so much Bu, and we dedicate this Halloween's Pug Social to your memory...

Sharon is putting together a menu that will include her specialty - Bow-Wow-Nies for the curly-tailed guests. Invite your pug friends, kids are welcome and encouraged to bring a friend.  Pugs are encouraged to bring their best costumes.  There will be prizes!  

There will be contests, games, and prizes, food and fun!!   Let's make this the biggest Howl-o-ween bash yet.  Do it for Bu!

This is our favorite location - a quiet, rural side street with plenty of parking, a HUGE fenced yard, plenty of chairs, and lots and lots of flat grassy green space to run and run and run - plenty big enough for our annual Halloween Pug races!  We can't wait to see you there.  This party is the highlight of the Puggie social season - please come, and invite another pug to come with you! You KNOW you know one!!

Our gracious hosts will be providing the food for this Halloween meetup, but feel free to bring your own Halloween themed snacks. Feel free to bring snacks for the Pugs, but try to bring soft snacks so that Clovis can have some too!

If you are coming to your first meetup, please be sure to let us know, so we can introduce you to everyone and make you and your Puggies feel welcome!

WOULD YOU LIKE TO HOST A MEETUP?

Please let your organizer know!

We try to schedule the meetups far enough in advance so that you can plan your Puggies' social calendar! Please note that the meetups usually take place at at Assistant Organizer Sharon's home in Carver - where Buford, Millie, and Max hang out - with occasional meetups taking place at your Organizer Charlotte Creeley's home in Brockton - at Casa Clovis and Cletus. However, we are always delighted to change the venue when someone else wants to host a meetup! For those who haven't hosted before, but would like to try, and if you do have a fenced yard large enough to accommodate anywhere from 20 to 40 Puggies and a few assorted other small breeds, please let your organizer know. We would like to give everyone a chance to host who would like to host! It's fun!

ABOUT THE MEETUPS

We're all responsible Pug owners here, so don't be concerned about your babies. Wherever we meet, we'll make sure to have shade and plenty of water for keeping Pugs cool. There will be soft drinks and something to snack on for the people attending! If you bring treats for the Pugs, please ONLY hand out treats when you can keep an eye on the dogs, DON'T FEED CLOVIS, and PLEASE BE SURE that nothing gets dropped - your organizer has a Pug (yes, that would be Clovis...) who has brain damage which makes it very difficult for him to swallow. I don't want Clovis to choke to death on a stolen treat, and I'm sure no one else does either.. Thank you for your consideration!

Other small dogs are welcome, but please ask in advance if you can bring dogs other than Pugs. If you have a little Puggie roughneck on your hands, you can bring him too - but be prepared to keep an eye on him. If he starts bullying or being too rough with another dog, give him a time out until he can get himself under control. We want everyone to have fun!

Your organizer pays $89.84 twice a year in January and July for the privilege of organizing the South of Boston Pug Meetups, and believe me, it's worth every penny for the fun we have. If you would like to help defray the costs, please make a voluntary contribution of $1.00 to Charlotte Creeley each time you attend. Remember, it's VOLUNTARY - even if I had to pay twice as much, it would be worth it for the just to see the smile on Clovis's and Cletus's faces when the Puggie meetups roll around.
results.name: THE BUFORD MEMORIAL  PUG HALLOWEEN MEETUP!!

results.description:
This will be the first meeting for those interested in reading and discussing the lectures from MIT prof Scott Aaronson's course on quantum computing. The course appears to cut across a really interesting range of fields, from set theory to complexity (P = NP), and what QM might be able to tell us about these topics (or maybe, what the math can tell us about QM, i.e. about reality!).

We'll try to cover the first two lectures in the first meeting, since the first lecture seems to be both on the short side and mostly background/history.

The lectures can be found here.

After this first meeting, we will aim to meet and cover one lecture approximately every two weeks.

******************************************************

A NOTE ON THE LOCATION: For first-timers, getting into the building can be a bit tricky. See this page for a map and explanation.
results.name: Quantum Computing Study Group - Lectures 1 and 2

results.description:
In this FREE mini-workshop, you'll learn specific tools that you can use right away to master intimate connections that are meaningful and loving.  

Spend your Sunday Creating More Love In Your Life with a group of like-minded friends (old and new!)


If this feels scary to you and you've been holding yourself back, this workshop is for you! 

Discover what's in your way of having the most satisfying  relationships including effective communication, and great sex. 

This workshop will focus on our innate ability to open to a greater love inside ourselves - that can be shared with others: a skill that when learned and practiced, enhances all of our relationships.  Feeling deeply connected to yourself and your heart provides a deep sense of peace. 

You’ll learn specific tools that will:

• Enhance your ability to identify core wants, needs and desires 

• Cultivate communication for healthy relating

• Become more intimate with yourself and others - with ease! 

• Stay in a place of love when it’s most difficult

In this free mini-workshop, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with others through a variety of exercises designed to open your heart and support you in sharing authentically with one another.

Come and get a taste of what you’ve been craving in a totally safe, warm, loving and non-sexual environment.  Learn more about what the Human Awareness Institute has to offer.

Finding love and being in love every day is something I personally never dreamed was possible (only for 'others' and not for me!)  Well, I'm happy to say I was wrong and am really excited to share what I've learned with you.

Each event begins promptly at the scheduled time. Please arrive at 1:45 pm so you can settle in, register and meet a few folks before we begin promptly.   

There will be no admittance after the scheduled start time so as not to break the continuity of the workshop.  



We look forward to seeing you there!  Even if you've been to a mini-workshop before, please join us again!  There's no limit to how many you can attend!  

** Please note there are cats in the farmhouse **
results.name: Create More Love In Your Life!

results.description:
We will watch "Salt of This Sea" (2008; 109 minutes), written and directed by Annemarie Jacir - the first feature film made by a Palestinian woman.  

Afterward, we'll let the film serve as our entry point for discussion of the people and politics of Palestine and Israel.  

Our intention is to create a welcoming space in which we can share our inwardly conflicted views and uncertainties; acknowledge and take responsibility for our personal stakes and prejudices as best we can; and be heard with love and respect, without fear of someone jumping down our throats.


- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -


SYNOPSIS

Soraya, 28 (played by Palestinian American poet Suheir Hammad), born and raised in Brooklyn, decides to return to live in Palestine, the country her family was exiled from in 1948. 

On arriving in Ramallah, Soraya tries to recover her grandparent’s money, frozen in an account in Jaffa, but is refused by the bank. She meets Emad, a young Palestinian whose ambition, contrary to hers, is to leave forever. 

Tired of the constraints that dictate their lives, Soraya and Emad know in order to be free, they must take things into their own hands, even it means breaking the law. In this quest for life, we follow their trail through remains of a lost Palestine.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Want to know more about the film?  Here are three very different reviews (with a spoiler alert for the third):

http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129082782

https://electronicintifada.net/content/finding-sense-home-salt-sea/8184

http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/film/stranger-than-paradise#full
results.name: Palestine film and discussion

The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

results.description:
25 FREE Meetup member tickets up for grabs! Go to www.nephilharmonic.org and use code MEETUP at check out.

The New England Philharmonic (NEP) under the direction of Richard Pittman will present “Stepping Stones of the 20th Century: Celebrating the Life and Music of Gunther Schuller” to open their[masked] season on October 25 at 3 p.m. at the Tsai Performance Center. 

The concert will pay tribute to the life and music of NEP’s Composer Laureate from 2013 to 2015, the late MacArthur Genius and Pulitzer-Prize winning composer Gunther Schuller who died this past summer at the age of 89. The concert repertoire was selected by Mr. Pittman to reflect the musical styles of the 20th century that inspired Schuller. 

The evening will include Irving Fine’s Neoclassical “Toccata Concertante,” Anton von Webern’s twelve-tone “Six Pieces for Orchestra,” Maurice Ravel’s Impressionist “Shéhérazade,” featuring soprano Sarah Pelletier, and Dmitri Shostakovich’s Russian symphonic poem “October.” The concert will also feature the Boston premiere of Schuller’s 1994 composition, “The Past Is in the Present,” as well as an 11-minute documentary “The Past Is in The Present: At Home with Gunther Schuller” * that features the legendary composer reflecting on his life and seven-decade career.
results.name: The NEP's 10/25 concert tribute to Gunther Schuller

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

If I can't make it, Brian Boodman will run the Meetup in my place. For that reason, I will be scheduling the October and November Meetups (not the Thanksgiving Meetup) in his neighborhood.

Join us for a lively debate!

venue.address_1: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138
venue.name: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

results.description:
Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :10/25@5:00pm

results.description:
Let's join five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

results.description:
Join us for our last Full Moon Labyrinth Walk for the season at the Somerville Growing Center (just outside of Union Square). I offer this outdoor labyrinth walk gathering each month on the Sunday nearest the full moon - May through October.

We'll have a little introduction of walking for those new to labyrinths and some fun discussion about the moon's current astrology and energy we might tap into for reflection or inspiration.

After our contemplative walk, those who wish, may linger for more conversation, community and snacks !

** Note the time change for this one - we start at 5:00 instead of 5:30!! (sadly our late day light into evening is no more until next year!).
results.how_to_find_us: There's free parking on Vinal Ave. on Sundays. Also not far from the #87 bus along Somerville Ave.
results.name: Our last Sunday Evening Full Moon Labyrinth Walk for the season!

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 37-47 -SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

results.description:
“We tell ourselves stories in order to live." --Joan Didion


October is literary month, so what better subject to reflect on than the act of storytelling? And who better to represent the craft than Scheherazade?

You will find Scheherazade's mark wherever you care to look. Her stories continue to travel through space, time, and literary tradition. And the significance of her very act of telling them still reverberates.

Two very different writers considered her story and the consequences of her storytelling...and retold it.

In Haruki Murakami's Scheherazade, she is a free woman who visits a captive man and tells him stories of her life. Why does she do it?  (Find the story below.)

http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/10/13/scheherazade-3


Edgar Allan Poe's version picks up the thread on the 1,002nd night, right at Scheherazade's supposed happy ever after.  Does she continue to tell stories? And to what end? (Find story below.)

https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Works_of_the_Late_Edgar_Allan_Poe/Volume_1/The_Thousand-and-Second_Tale_of_Scheherazade
results.name: Mashup: Murakami's Scheherazade + Poe's The Thousand-And-Second Tale

results.description:
Come join us for a lively book discussion - The Geography of Bliss: One Grump's Search for the Happiest Places in the World

Part foreign affairs discourse, part humor, and part twisted self-help guide, The Geography of Bliss takes the reader from America to Iceland to India in search of happiness, or, in the crabby author's case, moments of "un-unhappiness." The book uses a beguiling mixture of travel, psychology, science and humor to investigate not what happiness is, but where it is. Are people in Switzerland happier because it is the most democratic country in the world? Do citizens of Qatar, awash in petrodollars, find joy in all that cash? Is the King of Bhutan a visionary for his initiative to calculate Gross National Happiness? Why is Asheville, North Carolina so damn happy? With engaging wit and surprising insights, Eric Weiner answers those questions and many others, offering travelers of all moods some interesting new ideas for sunnier destinations and dispositions.

From Publishers Weekly Starred Review. Fortified with Eeyoreish fatalism—I'm already unhappy. I have nothing to lose—Weiner set out on a yearlong quest to find the world's unheralded happy places. Having worked for years as an NPR foreign correspondent, he'd gone to many obscure spots, but usually to report bad news or terrible tragedies. Now he'd travel to countries like Iceland, Bhutan, Qatar, Holland, Switzerland, Thailand and India to try to figure out why residents tell positive psychology researchers that they're actually quite happy. At his first stop, Rotterdam's World Database of Happiness, Weiner is confronted with a few inconvenient truths. Contrary to expectations, neither greater social equality nor greater cultural diversity is associated with greater happiness. Iceland and Denmark are very homogeneous, but very happy; Qatar is extremely wealthy, but Weiner, at least, found it rather depressing. He wasn't too fond of the Swiss, either, uncomfortable with their quiet satisfaction, tinged with just a trace of smugness. In the end, he realized happiness isn't about economics or geography. Maybe it's not even personal so much as relational. In the end, Weiner's travel tales—eating rotten shark meat in Iceland, smoking hashish in Rotterdam, trying to meditate at an Indian ashram—provide great happiness for his readers.


We will be choosing a book for January at this meeting; please come with a book suggestion. We encourage all ages, both men and women.


This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are at Panera. Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Please be considerate and change your rsvp if you cannot attend. All no shows from previous meetings or current meeting will be bumped to the end of the wait list!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for large table with meetup sign or the book.
results.name: Book Group - The Geography of Bliss: One Grump's Search for the Happiest Places

results.description:
(Resurrecting this topic for Halloween, since we never got to discuss it because of Snowmageddon last winter...)


It's the end of the world as we know it, and I feel fiiiine...

We sang that song tongue-in-cheek in the happy-go-lucky 80s (well at least some of us aging types did). But from the growing popularity of Armageddon and dystopian themed works of fiction like Hunger Games, Interstellar, The Walking Dead, Maze Runner, etc., it's clear that the demise our kind and culture  somehow looms large in our collective psyche. Is this just a passing fad driven by fascination with the technology to present such stories in cinema, or are we trying to tell our conscious selves something through those fascinations? Perhaps we've seen the dreams of the industrial and technological revolutions not pan out for all, and seek some kind of comfort in the telling and articulation of our fears for an unknown future. In the decades to come, will humans look back quaintly on all this as a morbid obsession of the times, or are we somehow prescient of what's to come?


Join us for a thoughtful, if sobering discussion of our (perhaps irrational) fears of impending doom and gloom...and of course have a glass of your favorite beverage handy to raise, should one need a moment of feeling fine about it all.

Hope to see you there :)
results.name: Armageddon

To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>

results.description:
This is a place to share our souls and learn from others, NOT a place to promote any particular school of thoughts, beliefs, faiths, political views, etc. We must keep an open mind, respect each other, and agree to disagree. 

Meeting Agenda: 7pm-9pm

1. Get your coffee and introduce yourselves: 10-15 minutes

2. Introduce the stimulus: 5 minutes

3. Small team discussion: 15 minutes

• What soulful question do you want to ask?

• Why is this question relevant/important to you?

• Vote on the question to submit to the whole group.

4. Group discussion: 45-60 minutes

• Each team submits a soulful question and explain why this question is relevant/important.

• Vote on which question to discuss within the whole group.

• In depth group discussion on the chosen question. The conversations should be related to one’s personal experience.

5. Individual reflection: 10 minutes

• What is your takeaway from today’s discussion?

• How will it affect your future thinking?

6. Conclusion and plan for next meeting: 5 minutes
results.how_to_find_us: We will be at the back separate session of the dinning hall, which is accessible from the backdoor towards the parking lot. There will be a sign on the table saying "Soulful Cafe"
results.name: We will enjoy coffee and have soulful discussions inspired by a stimulus.

group.name: Soulful Cafe - Meaningful Conversation in Newton

results.description:
For decades, an open-to-the-personal-growth-community, candle lighting ceremony has been the traditional close to every Insight I seminar.  

"Sharing the light" of consciousness by helping each other is one of the founding metaphors of the Personal Growth Network.  Participate in the candle-lighting as you participate in PGN, your own candle signifying your own growing awareness of your life well-lived, while you help others to become more aware of their lives well-lived.

Joining in on the culminating ceremony of the Insight I allows us who did not participate in the seminar to connect to, and to take back into our own lives, some of the palpable positive energy, joy, and love generated by the participants in the seminar. 


The nominal starting time (8PM) is often delayed a bit, depending on what is happening inside the closed doors of seminar, but get there before the doors open for the ceremony.  

Expect an enjoyable, cathartic wave of joy, love, acceptance, and excitement.  

So, if you absolutely, positively cannot enjoy the transformation that is the Insight I seminar itself, at least take a little of its energy back into your own life.
results.name: Insight: Candle Lighting Ceremony

results.description:
It's week 6 of the 2015 Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing. FREE: The comedy club experience is called the Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing Company. The brewery and destination-taproom, which opened in April of 2105, opens Sunday nights as a showcase style stand-up comedy club open to the public 21+ with no cover charge or ticket fee. Guests are able to order charcuterie boards, dinner and pints during, before and after the show. With a Sunday night show time of 9PM there is ample free parking is available.

Season 1, the 2015 dates are as follows: September 13th, 20th and 27th, October 4th, 11th and 25th, November 1st 8th 15th and 22nd December 6th 13th 20th and 27th.

The opening night on September 6th filled to capacity and guests were entertained by 7 professional comedians and show host C.J. Browne. “We’re excited to offer a curated show of experienced local comedians. Since the room and setup require excellence the showcase is not an open mic night. We are absolutely psyched about the success of opening night. We played to a full house that loved the show.” Show performer Gary Peterson says “The Slumbrew comedy show was such a fun room to work, because the owners care about making it fun. A packed house of young heroes supporting the local scene makes this place special. It makes me happy to know something so cool is alive in Somerville.”
results.name: Liquid Courage Comedy!!!!!!

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Monday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
WE ARE BACK IN DAVIS SQUARE FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
What the experience of drumming offers:

* A peak experience that bonds all who share it
* An atmosphere of truth, support, and harmony
* Techniques to reduce tension, worry, and stress
* A tribal celebration in an indigenous tradition
* Open heart and mind to awareness of spirit.

Mamadou teaches the importance of the drum in the African culture to the community as a mode of communication and in the daily life.

West african drumming is not just music, but an experience of the heart, mind, and spirit. It evokes self-discovery, spiritual renewal, joy for life, and a deep sense of community.

Each class is $10 per person.
results.why:
Mamadou has been teaching African drum in the North Shore area for over 10 years. He has an inherent talent for sharing his abilities with others. Let him teach you how to feel the rhythms of West Africa.

Plus, its a lot of fun :)
results.how_to_find_us: Near the main entrance to Cinema Salem at the Peabody-Essex Mall in downtown Salem.  Accessible from the MBTA Salem train and bus station.

results.description:
How do you build empathy in difficult to access contexts? Come to our inaugural Meetup to hear and discuss! The format will be a series of vignettes, followed by active discussion. We will hear from: 

• Christina Bosch, an Instructional Designer and Research Associate at CAST, on building empathy for incarcerated youth and the ecosystem of other folks around which those learners depend; and

• Christine Zanchi, Director of Student Innovation at Curriculum Associates, on the challenges of shedding adult assumptions in order to understand and build for learners in the k-2 classroom of today.

We’ll follow this with some consideration around the domain of Experience Design for Learning. And, we’ll cap off the evening by weighing topics for future Meetups. 

There will be light snacks and coffee available at the Meetup. There is also food for purchase in the cafe and Gather restaurant, both also located at District Hall.
Afterwards, join us for a brew at Gather (sorry, this part of the evening is not yet sponsored!). 


We look forward to seeing you, and please spread the word! The hashtag for the meetup is #edUX.

— Kim, for the Experience Design for Learning team
results.name: Building empathy in difficult to access contexts

results.description:
The Power of Tangible Things – Event link HERE.

Monday, October 26, 2015, 6pm


Harvard Museums of Science & Culture - Geological Lecture Hall, 24 Oxford Street

Free and open to the public. Free parking at 52 Oxford Street.

Lecture and book signing with: 

• Laurel Thatcher Ulrich, 300th Anniversary University Professor, Department of History, Harvard University

• Ivan Gaskell, Professor of Cultural History and Museum Studies, Bard Graduate Center: Decorative Arts, Design History, Material Culture

• Sara Schechner, David P. Wheatland Curator of the Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, Harvard University

• Sarah Anne Carter, Curator and Director of Research, The Chipstone FoundationSamantha van Gerbig, Photographer and Designer, Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, Harvard University

:: :: ::

In a world obsessed with the virtual, tangible things continue to mesmerize. In this program, the authors of Tangible Things: Making History through Objects will conduct a lively conversation about Harvard “stuff”: the books, manuscripts, artwork, scientific specimens, ethnographic artifacts, and historical relics found in the University’s world-class collections. The speakers will share perspectives on some of Harvard’s collected items and challenge people to discover new ways of looking at, organizing, and interpreting the tangible things in our environment.
results.name: Tangible Things

results.description:
The Bridge of a song is an important songwriting tool. It can be used many different ways. Let's discuss it' s function and give examples of what people consider to be successful bridges. Let's also talk about how to transition to the bridge? Change of key? What chords/melody will provide the lift that a bridge needs. Regardless of the key . Should we ascend to it? How long should it be? When exactly should it happen in a song. 

It's definitely something that I need to understand better.

As usual please brings snacks!!

See you all on the 26th.

Don't forget to have an example of a successful bridge from a songwriter or band that you admire.

Ellen :)
results.name: The "Bridge" and it's function.
