results.description:
New:

Due to time constraints and the game being very adjustable to new players joining and leaving at any time, I am making a change.

I do wish people to get something to compensate IHOP for letting us use the space, however, if you have not started or finished eating by 7:15pm please, start or finish eating at another table. The rest of the people will clean the table and start playing.  I want the rest of the players to have a chance to finish a game.


The rules give new players the opportunity to join the game at the start of any new hand, with the score of the mean player.

I am trying to keep the game and conversation balanced for everyone.  If multiple players are eating, conversing and playing,  the game may be held up until some people are restless.

Also, the more people eating and playing while handling the cards, the greater chance the few decks of "Jumbo Index" cards used for Negation Hearts will be marked and hard to shuffle, detracting from the game.

As always, please put your cold drinks on a napkin.

Thank you;

Negation Hearts Night. New players are VERY welcome: We will teach you how to play.

It is suggested that you get a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment. .

PUBLIC:

Both: The 450 and 456 Buses have nearby stops. 

Negation Hearts is played with two decks of cards. Two of the same cards like two king of clubs negate and the next highest card of the suit lead takes the cards played. So, even playing a two has not been safe at times. The scoring and passing are slightly altered from "Cancellation" hearts so that new people can join in or leave at the start of any hand.

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced between the two.
results.name: Negation Hearts in Salem @ IHOP *

Please note the $2 will be refunded to you after the event.  We have found that free Meetups have a very high no-show rate, and so are trying this as a means to improve attendance.

The USDA and Microsoft are collaborating on an Innovation Challenge to help 

farmers be more efficient and effective.  The USDA has a tremendous amount of food supply, economic demand, and remote sensing data as part of its Agricultural Statistical Service (NASS) and Economic Research Service (ERS), the challenge is to explore how to make this data accessible and provide insights for potential users.  

Link to USDA Challenge

This series will focus on developing applications for this challenge which has a deadline for submissions of October 27th.  Each night of the series will include a tutorial on a particular aspect of using R that applies to this challenge.  For example, Web Applications using R Shiny will be one of the training sessions.

results.description:
Agenda 

• 6:30: Networking & Pizza

• 7:00: Presentations

Presentation 1: Optimize Your Site for Speed

Benjamin Cool

How to improve the performance of WordPress to squeeze the most out of your hosting plan, improve the user experience, and make the wp-admin fly.


Bio

Benjamin Cool is the Application Optimizer at A2 Hosting in Ann Arbor Michigan where he focuses on building “one click” tools for improving Web application performance.

Ben has over 16 years in web development experience, an M.S. in Computer Science from Eastern Michigan University and A Graduate Certificate in Artificial Intelligence. He often talks at and attends local WordPress Meetups in the Great Lakes Region, is an organizer for WordCamp Ann Arbor and has a passion for making the web faster and easier to use.


Presentation 2: Beyond Yoast: 7 Critical SEO Steps You are Probably Missing

Tony Guarnaccia

So you’ve implemented the popular SEO plugins, now what? Big Fish Results founder Tony Guarnaccia will offer the top tactics that he utilizes to help clients search engine optimize their WordPress websites. He’ll also offer suggestions on how to audit your site to ensure that SEO best practices are in place after you have updated your site.


Bio

With over 15 years digital marketing experience working with thousands of small businesses as well as a dozen Fortune 500 companies, Tony founded Big Fish Results to help businesses of all sizes achieve market leadership using the same digital marketing strategy, tools and tactics that are normally reserved for large enterprises.  Some of the market leaders he has worked with include General Motors, ADP, Foster Grant, AutoNation and Ford Motor Company. He supports World Vision to bring drinkable water to children across the globe and Save the Bay to protect our natural resources here in Rhode Island.
results.name: Optimize Your Site for Speed & Beyond Yoast: 7 Critical SEO Steps

results.description:
October's book is Trauma by Michael Palmer:

Dr Carrie Bryant, a young neurosurgeon is a highly regarded doctor in residence at White Memorial hospital. Due to scheduling difficulties she is given a chance to do her first unsupervised brain surgery. She performs the difficult procedure but unforeseen complications arise. While exhausted Carrie has to rush back to her patient and makes a tragic mistake resulting in permanent brain damage for the woman she has operated on.
During the inquest looking into the operation Carrie feels impelled to resign her position at White Memorial. She moves back into her parent's house in order to get herself together to continue with her medical career. Her brother Adam, a returning veteran suffering from PTSD after being in combat also lives there and his condition leads Carrie into exploring another, different job.
When Carrie learns about a new technique involving Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) being tested as a treatment for the emotional and memory trauma occurring in PTSD by the VA she decides to enter that program as a surgeon and as a way back into medicine. Her first operation is successful, but amazingly the patient mysteriously vanishes.

results.description:
Discover the holistic benefits of the Feldenkrais Method®!

Each 90 minute Awareness Through Movement class consists of guided attention through carefully sequenced movements that are designed to stimulate your curiosity, challenge your coordination, and bring you into a new way of being in both body and mind.


By encouraging us to slow down, reduce effort, and delve into the building blocks of our movement, Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement enables us to discover previously unnoticed areas of habitual tension and unlock new possibilities for moving freely.  Come and experience for yourself what an effective resource it can be for stress relief, improving balance and posture, and alleviating chronic pain at the source. 

Classes are open to adults at all fitness levels. No prior experience necessary.  

Drop-ins are welcome, but RSVPing will give you the opportunity to influence the content of the class for your needs and interests!
results.name: Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement® class!
Talk on animal cognition at Harvard

results.description:
Harvard College Effective Altruism

 presents:

https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/?ui=2&ik=adf2c21f8a&view=fimg&th=1507d2c19221a9df&attid=0.1&disp=emb&realattid=d4b8c49c85159b26_0.1.1&attbid=ANGjdJ-3sWv7-HC91BArVTTb6xfdglolH5i6Y_zg3OYBwEoevVpxAIX9IiD-HrJiOMwGPhIUcRU7uh7cGeixT4KQkoNJt8Esmh9qyxTV4kHfhxjFmESjazeH5KJSOew&sz=w1180&ats=1445209063172&rm=1507d2c19221a9df&zw&atsh=1

RSVP Here !

Dr. Irene Pepperberg is a researcher at Harvard University in the field of animal cognition, specifically of African Grey parrots. Her work began with Alex, a parrot who was shown to have the emotional age of about a 2 year old child and the intelligence of up to a 5-6 year old child. Her research in areas such as the labelling of objects, shapes, colors, and the understanding of categorical concepts, of bigger-or-smaller, same-different, and nonhuman numerical abilities, revolutionized what the world knew about avian cognition. 

Arguments for human consciousness usually derive from introspective reports; we lack such reports for nonhumans. Not being able to derive data to posit human-like consciousness, Dr. Pepperberg argues that nonhumans have, at the least, a sense of awareness, which may or may not be distinct from full consciousness. She proposes that this awareness if required for complex tasks and is a form of higher order cognition. 

http://www.harvardea.org/events/
results.name: Animal Cognition, Consciousness, and Ethics (Harvard Effective Altruism)

Trish Matthies has been privately channeling the messages and healings of ascended masters for years, but now feels it is time to share this experience with you!


In the energy of the Full Moon,  this unique evening welcomes the feminine energy of the Triple Goddess connected to the moon phases as Maiden, Mother, and Crone (Grandmother). During the guided meditation you will ask the Goddess for assistance with a personal intention and listen to her pre-Channeled Message by Trish. The Triple Goddess will then offer her energy as a hands on healing channeled thru Trish. The room will be enhanced with a Crystal Grid to heighten the room's vibration and to open your crown and brow chakras to intuition and the divine feminine.  I invite you to wear white or purple.

The seating for this event is very limited in size to allow for attendants to have more hands on healing time. Please pre-register and with prepayment in advance to hold your spot.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:

1. You must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, send Tucker a message.  You might also consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 48 hours, or frequently cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, all of the above applies to you and your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

Update (10/15): In order to accommodate more people in the room, and maintain an easygoing environment for conversation and game playing, we ask that you please save loud games (like those with real-time arguing) for later in the evening, when the room is less full.  Typically this means 9:30 or later.


OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).

results.description:
2 Player Games, ANY Game (Previously X-Wing Miniatures)

An opportunity to play those two player games that we do not play on a regular (mostly euro?) boardgaming night.  

If we have an odd number of players, or if we just feel like it, yes, it is fine doing a 3, 4 or 5 player game as well. 

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played? 


Anything.  Bring anything that you think will gather enough interest.  Examples: Netrunner, Marvel Dice Masters, Memoir '44, Twilight Struggle, Few Acres of Snow or even chess if that is your thing.  Put other suggestions on the event comments.

Will try this format a couple of times to see how it goes.

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q. What About X-Wing?
A. If you noticed, this spot is filling up the time previously scheduled for X-Wing Miniatures 100pts - so... as you may have guessed, Randy and I will be setting up a couple of x-wing miniatures tables for those of us inclined towards that game but still want to make the event more inclusive to other game genres (it is not often the wife allows me to invite my friends to play games, so I better make the best use of the time).

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
We planned to do this trip on Sunday 10/25 but the weather didn't cooperate - would like to get it done before the end of the month and the forecast for Tuesday 10/27 looks really good!

=====

Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to four of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Monroe, Eisenhower, Pierce, and Jackson. We will use Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail to reach the ridge and then we will follow Mount Monroe Loop and Crawford Path, Webster Cliff Trail, and Webster Jackson Trail to climb over each of the summits. There will be a few steep sections on the way up to Monroe and then we will be above treeline until we reach Eisenhower. The Madison Spring Hut is already closed for the season and the Mizpah Hut closes on October 17th.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 12.6 miles and climb about 4,700 feet. It should take an average hiker about 8 hours 45 minutes to complete. This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/4-Mt-Monroe-5384


http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/11-Mt-Eisenhower-4780--27-Mt-Pierce-4310


http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/38-Mt-Jackson-4052


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.32544431762692&lat=44.25394950858018#.ViAquLTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


IT'S WINTER IN THE MOUNTAINS - WINTER CLOTHING AND GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS HIKE. DON'T THINK WE WILL NEED SNOWSHOES BUT WINTER BOOTS, TRACTION, AND WEATHER APPROPRIATE CLOTHING IS REQUIRED. EXPERIENCE IN WINTER IS ALSO REQUIRED.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike: 

</a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Webster Jackson Trailhead which is located on the south side of Route 302 about a half mile south of the AMC's Highland Center. According to Google Maps this spot is about 160 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 42 minutes to drive there. Since that is where we will end our trip we will leave a few cars there and drive to the start.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/D8E8SgFqMat


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Mindful Movement is a fusion of Buddhist meditation and Hatha yoga. No previous meditation or yoga experience is required,this is a gentle class where it's not  important where your foot is exactly, but more important THAT YOU KNOW YOU HAVE A FOOT!  You might find that when we move half as fast ,we can feel twice as much. Class is 75 minutes long and is held in a beautiful old stone cottage that has been converted to a yoga studio.  

Mindful movement is offered Tuesdays by our meditation teacher ,Randy Hicks, who also leads a sitting Meditation Group on Thursday evenings at 5:30 and a Sunrise yoga class at 6:00 am on Wednesday mornings.

 Your first class is freely offered, after that you can join the yoga studio for 30 days of unlimited classes for only $30.

There is usually 4 or 5 people in this group, even though most don't RSVP on meetup, so don't feel that you'll be the only one there ,even if you don't see any other RSVP s .

results.description:
Join the NEU Biotech Entrepreneurs as we welcome Dr. Ibraheem Badejo, Senior Director of New Ventures at Johnson & Johnson. Dr. Badejo leverages his expertise in smart materials and biomaterials to support the medical device sector.

Please RSVP via this link (EventBrite registration is necessary to be admitted):

Free Eventbrite Registration: http://www.eventbrite.com/o/northeastern-university-biotech-entrepreneurs-8446641482?s=45559043 

From 2010 to 2013, he was a Research Fellow at Global Surgery Group of Johnson & Johnson, where he was responsible for external and front-end innovations and intellectual property for Ethicon Biosurgery. From 2006 to 2010, he was the Director of Applied Research & New Technology Assessment of novel biomaterials. Prior to that, he was the Chief Scientist of Closure Medical Corp (acquired by J&J in 2005). Prior to joining Closure, he held various positions at Bayer, North Carolina State University, College of Charleston. He currently serves as an Adjunct Professor of Biomedical Engineering at Drexel University.

During his career, Dr. Badejo has led teams in the development of commercialized biomaterials based products and new technology / products licensed or acquired.

He received his BA degree in chemistry from Avila University. He received his PhD in Organic chemistry from the University of Toledo, where he was the Robert Whiteford Memorial Scholar for Outstanding Graduate Research and a Petroleum Research Fund Fellow. He is also the recipient of 24 US patents with others pending.

Dr. Badejo will be sharing his experiences, how he climbed the corporate ladder, and what he looks for in new ventures. He will be sharing valuable information on whats hot in biotech currently and what areas still need to be improved upon. We can assure you that this isn't a talk you'll want to miss. Following his talk, there will be a Q&A and networking session where you can meet with Dr. Badejo, as well as the Biotech Entrepreneurs team.

This event is FREE and open to the public.
results.how_to_find_us: 325 Behrakis Health Science Center
results.name: What's Hot In Biotech with NEU Biotech Entrepreneurs

results.description:
While Convolutional Neuronal Network (CNN) is not a new topic, it is not until 2013 that this topic got  huge attention from academia and industry. Indeed, the overwhelming majority of the talks at the 2015 CVPR conference where about deep learning. Also, companies that are involved in big data such as Google, Facebook, and many others, have invested heavily in topics related to CNNs.

CNNs have outperformed most vision algorithms in classification tasks. Deep learning is revolutionizing vision and artificial intelligence.

Innovative companies will present recent advances and applications in deep learning for vision at our October meetup.

Rough agenda:

6 - 6:30:  Networking and Pizza

6:30 - 7:20:  Speakers 

 (1)  Professor Tomaso Poggio from MIT, "Visual Cortex and Deep Networks".


(2) Daniel McDuff from Affectiva, "Deep Emotion Learning: Mining the World’s Largest Facial Expression Dataset".

 (3) Barton Fiske from Nvidia, "Accelerated Deep Learning with GPU’s".

7:20 - 7:30:  1 min pitches from audience. Need help? Looking for a job? Let us know. 

7:30 on:  More networking.

Location/Parking: the Microsoft NERD center is a short walk from the Kendall Sq. T stop, located adjacent to the Charles River.  There's usually street-parking to be found on side streets (such as Ames St.). There's also a garage in the NERD center, $10 flat fee after 4pm. Just remember to bring your ID to get into the NERD center.
results.name: Deep Learning and Vision

results.description:
Code "kata" night is back by popular demand! Learn CSS by doing!


You have seen JavaScript/Node.js and Ruby on Rails hackathons (also known as Hack Day, hackfest or codefest) but why not a css hackathon?

CASCADE BOS will hold our second CSS Hack Night on Tuesday, October 27, 2015 at Bocoup!

Hack night will start 6 p.m., but feel free to drop in anytime after 6 (will go till about 8:30). We will have "code kata" challenge for you to solve. Code Kata is a great way to try out new css tricks or try creative solutions without real consequences. It is "learning by doing." To get an idea, see last CSS Hack Night.

results.description:
Hello Cloudsters!

Please join us on Tuesday, the 27th of October, for some great talks, networking and refreshments.  We expect to have two separate presentations, along with ample time for questions and discussion.  This post will be updated with details on the second speaker and on the specifics of the refreshments shortly.

First Presentation:

"Building a Reseller Channel for Cloud Services," by Jeff Schmitt


The number of Cloud Services Providers and Cloud based offerings are exploding in the marketplace. Getting these innovative cloud offerings in front of the right customers can be a challenge, thus many firms are looking to the traditional IT VAR channel as a route to market. In this presentation Jeff Schmitt will discuss what to look for in a VAR (Solution Provider) Investments a solution provider needs to make, and review some personal successes and failures bring cloud services to mark via the channel.

About Jeff:  

Jeff has been working with Solutions Providers for the past 15 years, first at EMC corporation where he ran the channel services organization, and most recently, at CenturyCloud, where he was responsible for channel strategy and partner enablement.

Second Presentation:

"The Economics of Buying and Selling Cloud Services Through the Channel," by Brian Singer


Companies are spending more than ever on cloud services, with AWS recently eclipsing $2 billion in quarterly sales. Against this backdrop, channel providers face difficult choices, with shrinking resale margins and customers that demand responsiveness. In this talk, Brian Singer will draw on his experience at Orbitera working with dozens of channel organizations to provide a clear understanding of how to build margin in a cloud-focused business, how cloud impacts the economics of the channel, and what to look for when working with a cloud managed services or channel provider.


Brian Singer is the Co-Founder of Orbitera, a cloud commerce startup. Prior to Orbitera, Brian had key roles in Business Development and Product Marketing at BMC and Novell. Brian earned his MBA from the MIT Sloan School and holds a degree in Computer Engineering from Brown University.

Format:

6:00 - Networking/Refreshments/Pizza

6:30/45 - First Presentation

10 Minute Break

7:30/45 - Second Presentation

8:30 - End - Discussion & Networking
results.name: Building a Reseller Channel for Cloud Services

results.description:
We have some awesome talks for October's meetup!

1. Calls between Go & C/C++: Static/Dynamic/Awesome


Go can call C statically or dynamically using cgo. We'll do a cgo hello world, then show how to write a Go wrapper for a C library (the LPSolve linear programming solver).

Calling C++ from Go works too but it's trickier given the C++ calling conventions. We'll see an example of calling C++ from Go via a C wrapper function and also show how to generate Go wrapper code for a C++ class using SWIG.

You can also call Go from other languages! We'll briefly show how to call from C to Go in the same program, and how to compile a Go shared library to be used by Python, Ruby, etc.

Finally we'll touch on the performance and concurrency implications of calling between languages as it relates to Go

About the Speaker

Dave Raffensperger works as a software developer for Cru, a global nonprofit that provides spiritual mentoring and social entrepreneurship. He studied Computer Science at Northwestern University, and enjoys philosophy, algorithms and a good laugh. 

His blog is davidraff.com and he's @draffensperger on GitHub and Twitter. He likes the efficiency and pragmatic elegance of Go.

2. Microservices in Go

A microservices architecture can provide a structure that makes scalability and maintainability a lot easier for complex web applications. This talk will cover how to think about microservices in Go and examine the architecture of a couple of production systems.

About the Speaker

Kent Quirk (@kentquirk) has 30-some years of software engineering experience in an enormous variety of environments. He spent 15 years in the game industry and led engineering teams at Linden Lab and Disney. For the last two years he has been building web-based software, including microservices backends in Go, for a couple of different nonprofit organizations.
results.name: October Meetup: Calls between Go & C/C++ and Microservices In Go

Do you know what the Red Flags are and how to spot them? Does your profile actually have any? Does your picture truly say what you want it to say?

Learn this and many more tips on writing an attractive profile along with many dating tips from Leading Relationship Expert Deborah Knight. http://www.coachdeborahknight.com/

Deborah will lead you through a hands on workshop designed to rewrite your profile for your greatest success. She will help you put into words the true essence of who you are and what you are looking for. Arrive prepared to work on your profile! You will need your laptop and or a hard copy of your profile for this workshop. With Deborah’s guidance you will be split up into smaller groups to help one another with what you have learned so that you will all leave with a more streamlined profile that showcases who you really are and attracts someone who is looking for those exact qualities!

Jon Fischer is a Boston area Professional Photographer who specializes in Online Dating Profile Photos. Jon will explain his process of capturing your true essence.  He will also share a few tips so you will be able to do it on your own. Maybe you can end up liking getting your picture taken and even loving your photos. Is this possible ??  

Bring your laptops!

results.description:
Felipe Hoffa from Google Mountain View CA is joining us at Google Cambridge to give a talk on Tuesday October 27 at 6:30PM about using massive public data sets and Google BigQuery. Details and registration can be found on the </a><a href="http://www.meetup.com/gdg-boston/events/226088717/">GDG Boston page.

BigQuery is a RESTful web service that enables interactive analysis of massively large datasets working in conjunction with Google Storage.

Felippe is very active on social media about large datasets, BigQuery and analytics. The best entry point is his twitter handle: @felipehoffa.

Also Google engineers Ray Tsang and Brett McGowan will end the evening with a short talk about Cloud Spin a project that synchronizes multiple smartphone cameras to create a 180 degree image animation. Details and registration can be also be found on the GDG Boston page.
results.name: Join us: Felipe Hoffa on Massive Public Data Sets and Google BigQuery

results.description:
** Please Note: Registration with a full first and last name is required by Google building security. So, make sure to edit your meetup profile First & Last Number for Building Access! Thank you **

This event is coörganized with Boston Android and the Boston Analytic Club 

We have two talks that fit the GDG Boston developer community - tangible examples about producing results: 1) why, where and how to use BigQuery demonstrated with large public data sets and 2) Cloud Spin, a fun imaging app that is a use case that explains building apps with Android and Firebase. Both talks will leave you with tangible examples that you can take away with you study, modify and learn. 

An in-depth look at Google BigQuery Architecture by Felipe Hoffa of Google

Abstract: Come learn about Google BigQuery and its underlying architecture. Felipe will recount the evolution of BigQuery and explain the underlying principles of BigQuery and Dremel. Felipe will describe a few of the latest use cases and will demonstrate a use case of Google BigQuery

Speaker Bio: Felipe Hoffa moved from Chile to San Francisco to join Google as a Software Engineer. Since 2013 he's been a Developer Advocate on big data - to inspire developers around the world to leverage the Google Cloud Platform tools to analyze and understand their data in ways they could never before. You can find him in several YouTube videos, blog posts, and conferences around the world. Follow Felipe on Twitter at @felipehoffa.

Cloud Spin - how to build rigging and software to take a 180 degree animated image

Synopsis: Cloud Spin is a project built to demonstrate Firebase and Android. Multiple Android smartphone cameras are synchronized to record videos that render a 180 animated image. Here’s what the team did:

• Built physical staging rig to hold the Android smartphones

• Orchestrated video recording on all the phones with Firebase

• Recorded and saved the video using the Camera API

• Uploaded the video to Google Cloud Platform for processing

You’ll get to see the prototype rig, get a 180-spin shot of yourself and hear how the mobile and cloud apps were built. You can learn more about Cloud Spin here, and see the latest cloud spin images on Twitter at https://twitter.com/googlecloudspin

Speaker Bio: Ray Tsang is a Developer Advocate for the Google Cloud Platform.  Ray had extensive hands on cross-industry enterprise systems integration delivery and management experiences.  Follow Ray at @saturnism. 

Speaker Bio: Bret McGowen is a Developer Advocate on the Google Cloud Platform team. Prior to Google, Bret worked at a variety of enterprises and startups, including at Rackspace as a software engineer. Follow Bret at @bretmcg.
results.name: Joint Event: Google Cloud Talks - Big Query and Cloud Spin

results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog

results.description:
We have two great Google Cloud talks for the evening:

• BigQuery -  why, where and how to use BigQuery demonstrated with large public data sets

• Cloud Spin - a fun imaging app that is a use case that explains building apps with Android and Firebase. 

Both talks will leave you with tangible examples that you can take away with you study, modify and learn.


This event is co-organized with Boston Android and the Boston Analytic Club.


An in-depth look at Google BigQuery Architecture by Felipe Hoffa of Google

Come learn about Google BigQuery and its underlying architecture. Felipe will recount the evolution of BigQuery and explain the underlying principles of BigQuery and Dremel. Felipe will describe a few of the latest use cases and will demonstrate a use case of Google BigQuery

Felipe Hoffa moved from Chile to San Francisco to join Google as a Software Engineer. Since 2013 he's been a Developer Advocate on big data - to inspire developers around the world to leverage the Google Cloud Platform tools to analyze and understand their data in ways they could never before. You can find him in several YouTube videos, blog posts, and conferences around the world. Follow Felipe on Twitter at @felipehoffa.

Cloud Spin - how to build rigging and software to take a 180 degree animated image

Cloud Spin is a project built to demonstrate Firebase and Android. Multiple Android smartphone cameras are synchronized to record videos that render a 180 animated image. Here’s what the team did:

• Built physical staging rig to hold the Android smartphones

• Orchestrated video recording on all the phones with Firebase

• Recorded and saved the video using the Camera API

• Uploaded the video to Google Cloud Platform for processing

You’ll get to see the prototype rig, get a 180-spin shot of yourself and hear how the mobile and cloud apps were built. You can learn more about Cloud Spin here, and see the latest cloud spin images on Twitter at https://twitter.com/googlecloudspin

Ray Tsang is a Developer Advocate for the Google Cloud Platform.  Ray had extensive hands on cross-industry enterprise systems integration delivery and management experiences.  Follow Ray at @saturnism. 

Bret McGowen is a Developer Advocate on the Google Cloud Platform team. Prior to Google, Bret worked at a variety of enterprises and startups, including at Rackspace as a software engineer. Follow Bret at @bretmcg.
results.name: Google Cloud Talks - BigQuery and Cloud Spin

The New England Progress User’s Group is holding a kick off meeting on Tuesday evening Oct 27, 2015.  We will start at 6:30 pm.  The meeting will be held at the Progress Corporate offices 14 Oak Park Drive, Bedford, Mass.

We expect to serve pizza and beverages to start.  We will using the opening as a time to welcome back the familiar and introduce the new. Everybody that uses a Progress technology is invited to attend with an initial emphasis on the OpenEdge product line. Our opening topic will be:

What is new in the ABL by Fernando Souza.

This session provides an overview of the enhancements to the ABL that will be available in the 11.6 Release. These include support for ABL enumeration types, OOABL reflection as well as other topics.

Fernando Souza is a Principal Engineer on the OpenEdge Language team. He has been a part of the OpenEdge development team for over 10 years and part of Progress for over 15 years. He has an outstanding understanding of the OpenEdge language from an internal and users perspective.

We may have a second presentation on the Progress modernization strategy for OpenEdge applications.

Living in New England makes you very lucky.  We have access to all the Progress talent and corporate resources.  Progress, for their part, have fully embraced the User Group Community and are sponsoring our kickoff.

Please come and get involved.  Meet fellow users as well as the people behind the scenes of the greatest application tool set in the world.

results.description:
Have you ever found yourself lost in conversations around some of the 'lingo' used in anti-racism/social justice work?
Do you want to role-play problem solving scenarios around racist interactions?
Does the idea of racial affinity circles interest you?
Do you want to brush up on your understanding of how racism and intersectionality function in today's society?

If you have answered yes to any of these questions, this meetup is for you! As an activist community, it can become very easy for us to forget our roots. Why do we care so much? Why is racism so important for us to focus on? How does racism permeate in the structures and interactions of our daily lives?

This will be the first of reoccurring meetups that will help us refocus on the root of why we, the Boston Knapsack Anti-Racism Group, exist. Let's talk about racism at the core of what we do. In this meetup we will:
1. Go over key definitions that are used in anti-racist and social justice work.
2. Review the stages of racial identity development (used in critical race theory, by Beverly Daniel Tatum)
3. Reflect and grow on personal experiences: what brings you to this space and why do you keep coming back?
4. Role-play scenarios to practice interacting through confrontations about racism.
5. Work in racial affinity groups to discuss the roles, problems, and challenges unique to different racial groups.
6. And more!

This meetup is for anyone, from the folks new to anti-racist work to those who have been doing it for years.
results.how_to_find_us: This meetup will be held in the first floor conference room in the same building as the CCI office.  When you get to the building, dial #62 (this will call the phone and we will buzz you in). We'll have signs directing you to the room.
results.name: Racism: Back to the Basics

In partnership with the Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages store, MindfulBoston teachers will be leading a series of Compassion Meditation events as a service to our community. 
Place: 
The Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages is located at 
694 Massachusetts Avenue 
Central Square, Cambridge 02139 
Time: 
6:45pm to 8pm

Description: 
Being Aware of Being Loved allows participants an opportunity to connect to how much love is available to them, and to be more aware of that love in their daily lives.

Schedule: 
There will be an informal schedule. 
At about 6:45pm we'll set up some seats and have a chat about what meditation is about. This is the official start time for our event.

The front door will be locked by 7:01. Make sure to arrive either on-time or early! 
The store's registers will be closed by 7:05 so that employees can join us in meditation.

How to reserve your space:

Please rsvp here or call the store to rsvp. There are no "tickets" but we would like a head count in order to prepare a big enough space for sitting together.

Note: we typically have up to 30 people attend these events. RSVPing is pretty important because we need to move bookcases around to fit everybody in the space. Thanks! Seating: 
If you have hip/knee or other reasons to need a chair, make sure to rsvp here and say 'reserve a chair' in your comments. 
There are seven folding chairs and a few low stools. Zafu style cushions are sometimes available if the store has some in stock. But there are no guarantees. Most of us will be sitting on the floor. Feel free to bring your own pillow with you. What is planned: 
The hour (or so) that we spend together will include: discussion about compassionate healing for ourselves and each other, and an experience of lovingkindness meditation. The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 20 minutes long. No previous experience is required, the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand.

As many of you know, I am a former accountant turned competitive stand up paddlesurf competitor, coach and stand up paddleboard instructor who is from Hingham and lives in Braintree in the summer/fall and Costa Rica in the winter/spring organizing vacation packages! Since becoming knowledgable in Costa Rican culture, activities and accommodations, many of my friends, relatives and members of meetup began asking me to put together trips for them. results.description:
Science and Cooking returns! - A semester-long public lecture series that pairs Harvard University professors with popular chefs and food experts to showcase the science behind different cooking techniques. This lecture series is sponsored by the Harvard University John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 

Full schedule below and HERE. Free and open to the public. 

:: :: ::

Note date (Tuesday) and check location on this one! - S.

Lecture 7) <Location TBA> Tuesday, Oct. 27 - Viscosity and Polymers - José Andrés, (@chefjoseandres), ThinkFoodGroup

:: :: ::


These public lectures are based on the Harvard course “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” but do not replicate course content. Unless otherwise noted, all talks take place in the Harvard Science Center (1 Oxford St., Cambridge, Hall C) and begin at 7 p.m. Each presentation begins with a 15-minute lecture by a faculty member from the Harvard course, who will discuss one of the scientific topics from that week’s class. Seating for all lectures is first come, first seated. If you have questions regarding this public lecture series, please contact [masked]. 

:: :: ::

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tt9g2se1LcM&index=10&list=PL546CD09EA2399DAB


 Full schedule

Lecture 1) Monday, Sept. 7 - Thinking about Flavor - Dave Arnold (@CookingIssues), Booker & Dax, and host of “Cooking Issues” and Harold McGee (@Harold_McGee), writer, “Curious Cook”


Lecture 2) Monday, Sept. 14 - Pasta Magic - Mark Ladner, (@ChefMarkLadner), Del Posto

Lecture 3) Monday, Sept. 21 - The Science of Sugar - Joanne Chang ’91, (@jbchang), Flour Bakery, author of “Flour” and “Flour Too”

Lecture 4) Monday, Sept. 28 - Title TBA* - *Jim Lahey, (@jimlaheySSB), Sullivan Street Bakery

Lecture 5) Monday, Oct. 12 - Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting? - Andoni Aduriz, (@mugaritz), Mugaritz and Ramon Perisé, Mugaritz

Lecture 6) Monday, Oct. 19 - Heat Transfer to Capture Flavors - Josep Roca, (@CanRocaCeller), El Celler de Can Roca and Raül Sillero, El Celler de Can Roca

Lecture 7) <Location TBA> Tuesday, Oct. 27 - Viscosity and Polymers - José Andrés, (@chefjoseandres), ThinkFoodGroup

Lecture 8) Monday, Nov. 2 - Title TBA - Bryan Voltaggio, (@BryanVoltaggio), Volt*Michael Voltaggio, (@MVoltaggio), Ink

Lecture 9) Monday, Nov. 16 - Fermentation on Wheels: Food Education and Community Impact - Tara Whitsitt, (@tarawhitsitt), Fermentation on Wheels

Lecture 10) Monday, Nov. 23 - Title TBA - Nathan Myhrvold, (@ModernCuisine), former Chief Technology Officer of Microsoft, co-founder of Intellectual Ventures, author of “Modernist Cuisine”

Lecture 11) Monday, Dec. 7 - Title TBA - Tom Colicchio, (@tomcolicchio), “Top Chef” judge and chef/owner, Craft Hospitality, and Mei Lin, (@meilin21), “Top Chef” season 12 winner, and Gail Simmons, (@gailsimmons), “Top Chef” judge, Culinary expert, and Food & Wine magazine Special Projects Director

:: :: ::

The Harvard College Course: The Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) and the Alícia Foundation developed a General Education science course, “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” which debuted in the fall of 2010. The course uses food and cooking to explicate fundamental principles in applied physics and engineering. (Watch a video about the course.) Limited to currently enrolled Harvard undergraduates, the class brings together eminent Harvard researchers and world-class chefs. 

:: :: ::

A version of “Science and Cooking” is offered for credit through the Harvard Extension School. An online course will be offered in the fall and spring semesters. Registered students will have access to the expertise and support of Harvard teaching staff.

:: :: ::

For more info visit <a>www.seas.harvard.edu.</a>

results.description:
WHY ME?  Understanding Karma                                                                                                          a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | OCT 13th - NOV 17th


7:00 - 8:30pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis

Do you ever wonder why certain things, good or bad, happen to you? How can an understanding of Karma change things for the better?

Karma means ‘action’. Every action we perform leaves an imprint on our very subtle mind and each imprint eventually gives rise to its own effect. Our mind is like a field and performing actions is like sowing seeds in that field. In this series, we will explore Buddha’s teachings on Karma. We will learn how to apply its wisdom into our daily lives in beautiful meditations, so that we can learn to accept our present circumstances and joyfully cultivate our future happiness.

Each class includes a short talk and two guided meditations. Everyone welcome - no experience necessary.  

Drop in anytime! No need to pre-registration. 

Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
Deepening into the practice of Speaking Circle turns will support you in continuing  to develop full presence in front of groups.  Being in Relational Presence with your audience is the key.

Relational Presence, the foundation of Speaking Circles, is a precondition for all masterful communication. When this state becomes your default mode of approaching every communication, you effortlessly step into a natural flow. 

Developing your capacity for Relational Presence is like strengthening a muscle that has been neglected. Unlike the struggle that physical workouts are for many, this exercise is designed to be highly pleasurable. There may be some initial confusion, discomfort, self-doubt but hang in there and do the reps no matter how it feels or what you are thinking.  With practice you will find . . . 

* Speaking Circles support you to access your natural public presence, along with your capacity to unselfconsciously express passion and purpose.

* Reach hearts, minds and souls every time through the practice of being in a Speaking Circle.

* Transmit your message and content with ease to groups of any size by practicing attunement with one listener at a time.

* Give up conventional notions of "public speaking" and discover the magic of authentic intimacy with audiences.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.



Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

2.  Improved Balance

3.  Improved Flexibility

4.  Focus and stillness

5.  Hand and Eye Coordination

6.  Improved reflexes

7.  Learn self-defense skills

8.  Stress relief

9.  Relax

10.  Gain Self Confident and Self Respect

11.  Learn to Breathe

12.  Learn to Find Focus and Stillness

13.  Encouraging Non-Violent Conflict Resolution

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life

results.description:
Cambridge Center for Adult Education

Winter schedule HERE. Registration opens today (Oct. 28th). 

:: :: ::

<from the CCAE website>

The Cambridge Center for Adult Education provides high-quality educational opportunities for the diverse adults of Greater Boston. Sign up today for a class in Cooking, Art, Music, ESL, French, Spanish, Wine & Spirits and so much more. 

New classes start every week from now through Summer. Click on the topics above to explore our offerings or view a pdf of the Summer Catalog below.

For more than a century, the Cambridge Center for Adult Education (CCAE) has provided an oasis of learning in the midst of the busy commercial hub Harvard Square. 

Every year, more than 8000 adults take classes here.  They are looking for knowledge offered in an affordable, social setting in a safe, non-competitive atmosphere. We offer:

Extraordinary dedicated, knowledgeable teachersExperiential learning in small group classesAffordable course fees ensuring that classes have a mix of individuals from all walks of lifeA welcoming atmosphere that encourages connections, often shaping friendships that last a lifetimeNestled in two historic buildings - the William Brattle House (1727) and the Blacksmith House (1808) - CCAE is steps away from the Harvard Square T station, bus lines, and parking garages.  We offer homey classrooms inside, and inviting public spaces outside. The Brattle House courtyard encourages casual meetings by students, visitors and locals, while the café tables and umbrellas outside the Blacksmith House offer a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of Harvard Square.

Sign up for a class today, you belong here!

Herzum is presenting a one-hour webinar to introduce JIRA 7 and you’re invited.  Atlassian recently announced the general availability of JIRA 7 and you undoubtedly have questions about what this means to you.  Don’t worry, Herzum is ready and we’re looking out for you.  Join Herzum experts for a webinar on October 28 and we’ll get you prepared for the changes.  JIRA is now JIRA Software, JIRA Service Desk, and JIRA Core – three independent products with purpose-built experiences for software, service and IT, and business teams. 

• We’ll answer typical questions like:

• Why did Atlassian make this change?

• What does this change mean to my licensing and renewal?

• How does this impact my existing JIRA installation?

• What will happen when I upgrade to JIRA 7?

Find out what the future holds for your favorite project and task management solution.  Get specific insight into how licensing changes will affect your organization.  Learn what happened to JIRA Agile.  This focused webinar will also take some time for Q&A.

--->NOTE: This is a FREE DIGITAL EVENT at your location on your device where-ever you are!

REGISTER NOW: http://bit.ly/1P1qVp4

Very few leaders can become extraordinary when they possess fatal flaws. Steve Jobs, however, was able to do this. 

During this enlightening webinar, Dr. Jack Zenger and Dr. Joe Folkman will delve into the history of Steve Jobs’ and Apple’s success.

They will discuss:

What happens to the very few successful leaders with strengths but also fatal flaws

What we know about Steve Jobs’ strengths and flaws

What might have happened had Jobs been open to feedback

What positive aspects, if any, were caused by his negative behavior

Research that shows most leaders are blind about their own strengths and weaknesses

After registering you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the webinar. There is no fee to attend; however, seats are limited.

results.description:
This is a special Docker seminar at Harvard's CS50 course that is open to the public! Docker's Mano Marks and Nicola Kabar will present an introduction to Docker and containers. No need to register ahead of time - just show up to attend the presentation!

Watch the livestream: https://live.cs50.net/


ABSTRACT:

Docker is the name on the tip of many tongues at the moment. It is an open-source containerization engine which allows developers to package up an application in a container along with all the settings and software required to run it, and deploy with a minimum of fuss. Tens of thousands of developers currently use Docker for their development, testing, and deployment workflows. 

This session will introduce the Docker ecosystem, how it works, and how to build, share, and deploy Docker containers. 


SPEAKERS:

Mano Marks, Developer Relations Manager at Docker, Inc.

Nicola Kabar, Solutions Architect at Docker, Inc.
results.how_to_find_us: Room B101
results.name: Contain Yourself: An Intro to Docker and Containers

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street 
Mission Hill, Roxbury 
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops) 
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2). 

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).


We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm or so (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Use the T - #66 bus comes by - E-Line or Orange Line

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

results.description:
Want to learn Public Speaking but not sure where to start?

Are you afraid of speaking in front of groups?

Use filler words like 'um', 'and', 'like', 'you know'?

Have no idea how to structure an interesting speech? 

Then this is the place for you.

EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING

Our hands on class will give you a safe, supportive and fun atmosphere to practice public speaking with other beginners  who are also your supportive audience.


PERSONALIZED COACHING

When you sign up I'll ask you 1-2 specific goals you want to learn in class and I'll teach it to you!  

It's a customized syllabus designed by you.  

Not sure where to start? No worries, I'll teach you the beginning steps.

CREATE CONFIDENCE

Fear of speaking in front of a group?  

Not to worry...you'll learn the coping mechanisms the professionals use and the fear will turn to excitement!


VIDEO FEEDBACK

Optional video taping of your speech is available so you can see yourself and make your own evaluation.  

We upload your practice speeches to Dropbox and only the class students can see it later.  

We can also video tape with just your smartphone for super privacy.  

It's a powerful tool to evaluate yourself.


OTHER BENEFITS

Learn how to give a speech without notes and never forget what to say!


How about getting rid of those pesky 'ums', 'likes', 'you knows' and other filler words?  That's part of the class.


Have a specific project or presentation?  Practice it in this class.  


Let the President of Toastmasters Boston Copley share with you the basics of solid speech making.


Our small classes are designed to give you the individual attention, feedback and suggestions to help you thrive!

MONEY BACK GUARANTEE

If you feel it's not worth your money you get a 100% refund.  No questions asked.

SAVE $40

BRING A FRIEND AND YOU BOTH ATTEND THE 'PRACTICE + PERSONALIZED COACHING' CLASS ON THE SAME EVENING FOR FREE. A $40 VALUE.

See you there!
